[[Pain & Gain]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s thriller movies, 2010s comedy-drama movies, 2013 movies

Pain & Gain is a melodramatic 2013 criminal-comedy movie. It is about events which take place between late 1994 until mid 1995. These events involve several gangsters called The Sun Gym Gang. They kidnap several people, kill others, use steroids, rob armored vehicles and do certain drugs. The events within the movie, however, are fictionalized or made up versions for events that actually happened. The events did happen, although the real-life events are far different from those in Pain & Gain. The movie got mixed reviews, only half of which were good or positive. It performed well, though, in the overall box office. It was released April 26, 2013. Mark Wahlberg and Dwayne Johnson are in this movie.

[[Tommy Flowers]]

CATEGORIES: 1905 births, 1998 deaths, People from London, Civil servants, British engineers, Officers of the Order of the British Empire

Tommy Flowers OBE (Thomas Harold Flowers, 22 December 1905 – 28 October 1998) was a British engineer. During World War II, Flowers designed Colossus, the world's first programmable electronic computer, to help solve encrypted German messages.

The first Mark 1, with 1500 vacuum tube valves, ran at Dollis Hill in November 1943, and then at Bletchley Park in January 1944.

A Mark 2 redesign with 2,400 valves had begun before the first computer was finished. The first Mark 2 Colossus went into service at Bletchley Park on 1 June 1944, and immediately produced vital information for the imminent D-Day landing.

[[Penda of Mercia]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth unknown, 650s deaths, Kings and Queens of Mercia

Penda († 655) was a 7th century King of Mercia. He was a noble of the royal house of Mercia and a pagan his entire life. Penda was the central figure in English history from 632 until his death. Penda treated every Northumbrian king as his enemy, especially if that king had any influence in southern England.

[[P. G. T. Beauregard]]

CATEGORIES: 1818 births, 1893 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in the United States, Confederate Army generals, American inventors, Businesspeople from New Orleans, Louisiana, Politicians from New Orleans, Louisiana, Writers from New Orleans, Louisiana

Pierre Gustave Toutant Beauregard (May 28, 1818 – February 20, 1893) was an American military officer, politician, inventor, writer, civil servant. He was the first prominent general of the Confederate States Army during the American Civil War. Today, he is known as P. G. T. Beauregard, but he rarely used his first name as an adult.

[[Ken Hechler]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2016 deaths, American centenarians, Columbia University alumni, Episcopalians, Deaths from stroke, United States representatives from West Virginia, US Democratic Party politicians

Kenneth William "Ken" Hechler (September 20, 1914 – December 10, 2016) was an American politician. A member of the Democratic Party, he represented West Virginia in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1959 to 1977. Hechler was the West Virginia Secretary of State from 1985 to 2001. He was currently the oldest living person to have served in the United States Congress.

[[Unforgiven (2004)]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 in professional wrestling, History of Portland, Oregon, WWE Unforgiven, 2004 in American television, 21st century in Oregon

Unforgiven (2004) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). It was held on September 12, 2004 at the Rose Garden in Portland, Oregon. It was the sixth Unforgiven event held by the WWE.  

[[Jersey Girl (2004 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 comedy-drama movies, 2004 romance movies, 2000s romantic comedy movies, 2000s romantic drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, American romantic comedy movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies directed by Kevin Smith, Movies set in New Jersey, Movies set in New York City, Movies set in the 1990s, Screenplays by Kevin Smith

Jersey Girl is a 2004 American drama-comedy movie. It was written and directed by Kevin Smith. It was produced by Scott Mosier. It stars Ben Affleck, Liv Tyler, Raquel Castro, George Carlin, Jason Biggs, Jennifer Lopez, Stephen Root, and Will Smith. Jason Lee, Matt Damon, and Betty Aberlin had cameo appearances.  

It was released on March 26, 2004 to negative reviews. Critic Roger Ebert thought the movie was good because he gave it 3.5 out of 4 stars. 

[[Birmingham Central Library]]

CATEGORIES: Libraries in the United Kingdom, Buildings and structures in England, Birmingham, 1974 establishments in England, 2013 disestablishments in the United Kingdom, 21st century disestablishments in England

June 2018

Birmingham Central Library was the main public library in Birmingham, England. It closed on 29 June 2013 and was replaced with the Library of Birmingham.

It was once the largest non-national library in Europe. 

[[Pybba of Mercia]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth unknown, Year of death unknown, Kings and Queens of Mercia

Pybba († 606) (also Pibba or Wibba) was an early Anglian King of Mercia. He is the common ancestor of the Mercian kings in the four Mercian genealogies. As such he's considered by many historians to be the first known king of Mercia. He was the father of kings Penda and Eowa.

[[Gong Li]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, Chinese movie actors, Chinese television actors, Chinese stage actors, People who lost Chinese citizenship

Gong Li is a Chinese actress. She helped bring Chinese cinema to Europe and the United States.

She has several awards.  She received both the Golden Rooster and the Hundred Flowers Awards two times.  She also has the Berlinale Camera, Cannes Festival Trophy, National Board of Review, New York Film Critics Circle Award, and Volpi Cup.

Gong Li became a Goodwill Ambassador of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) on 16 October 2000.

[[St Paul's Girls' School]]

CATEGORIES: 1904 establishments in England, London Borough of Hammersmith and Fulham, Schools in London

St Paul's Girls' School is a private secondary school for girls in Hammersmith, London. The headmistress is Clarissa Farr. It was started by the Worshipful Company of Mercers in 1904 as a female version of St Paul's School. It is one of a few schools in England that does not have a uniform, but there are strict rules about 'cleavages, thighs and midriffs'. The students are called Paulinas.

St Paul's is ranked the best secondary school in London. In 2012, 99.1% of A Level grades were A*-B. In 2013 100% of GCSE results were A*-B (as in the four previous years) and 91.2% were A*, the highest percentage ever at the school or in the country. Famous women who were pupils there include Carol Thatcher, Rachel Weisz, Dodie Smith, Jennifer Saunders, Kitty Godfree, and Onora Sylvia O'Neill, Baroness O'Neill of Bengarve. 100% of Paulinas go on to university and 45% go to Cambridge or Oxford.

[[New Apostolic Church]]

CATEGORIES: Protestantism

The New Apostolic Church (NAC) is a Christian denomination. It divided from the Catholic Apostolic Church by the 1863 Schism of Hamburg. The church has congregations in all around the world and about 10 million members worldwide. The international head quarter of the New Apostolic Church is located in Zurich (Switzerland).

Charity and the Second Coming of Christ are the main ideas of the New Apostolic Church. Most of its ideas are related to mainstream Christianity. It also has a liturgy similar to Protestantism and it is organized like the Roman Catholic Church.

The church calls itself the Early Church. Its spiritual leaders call themselves Apostles.

[[Unforgiven (2003)]]

CATEGORIES: 2003 in professional wrestling, 2003 in American television, 2000s in Pennsylvania, Sports in Pennsylvania, WWE Unforgiven

Unforgiven (2003) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). It was held on September 21, 2003 at the Giant Center in Hershey, Pennsylvania. It was the sixth Unforgiven event held by the WWE.  

[[Coding theory]]

CATEGORIES: Theoretical computer science, Encodings

Coding theory is the study of properties of codes and how good they are for a use in the real world. Codes are used for data compression (where data is made smaller), cryptography (where data is changed into a form that not everyone can read), and error correction. Codes are studied by different scientific disciplines for designing data transmission methods that are efficient and reliable.

[[Wycombe Abbey]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in Buckinghamshire, 1896 establishments in England

Wycombe Abbey is a private secondary boarding school for girls in High Wycombe, England. It has one of the best girls' boarding school exam results in the United Kingdom. 

37% of students go on to Oxford or Cambridge universities. It was started in 1896 by Dame Frances Gove. The headmistress is Rhiannon Wilkinson. It costs £11,100 per term for boarders. All girls year 79 have to learn Latin. It is a Church of England school with its own chapel.

[[Lollardy]]

CATEGORIES: 14th century in Europe, Christianity of the Middle Ages

Lollard or Lollardy was a religious movement that started in the Middle Ages. It began in the middle of the 14th century during the English Reformation. "Lollard" is a word used to refer to those who believed in John Wycliffe's ideas.,  He was a well-known  theologian who was expelled from the University of Oxford in 1381 because he criticized the Catholic Church. He mainly did this using his teaching about the Eucharist. The Lollards wanted to reform Western Christianity.

[[Holiness movement]]

CATEGORIES: Evangelicalism, Christian movements and denominational families

The holiness movement is about certain of beliefs and practices that came from Methodism in the 19th-century. It also refers to some groups of evangelical Christianity  who believe that these ideas are central doctrine. The movement is distinguished by its focus on John Wesley's teaching of "Christian perfection" . It says that it is possible to live free of sin, and specifically by the belief that this can be done instantly by preforming a second work of grace.

[[John Chrysostom]]

CATEGORIES: 347 births, 407 deaths, Archbishops, Christian saints, Christian theologians, Eastern Orthodox Christians, Syrian Christians

John Chrysostom (c. 347–407) was an Archbishop of Constantinople and an important Early Church Father. He is known for his powerful and persuasive words in preaching and public speaking. After his death in 407 C.E., he was given the Greek title "chrysostomos", meaning "golden mouthed" in English.

The Orthodox and Eastern Catholic Churches see him as a saint. He is also recognized by the Eastern Orthodox Church and the Catholic Church as a saint. Western Churches, including the Roman Catholic Church, some Anglican Churches, and parts of the Lutheran Church, celebrate him by making 13 September a holiday. They also celebrate an Eastern feast day of 27 January. The Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria also recognizes John Chrysostom as a saint.

John is known mainly as a preacher in Christianity, as well as a theologian and liturgist.

[[FAO Goodwill Ambassador]]

CATEGORIES: United Nations, 1999 establishments

The FAO Goodwill Ambassadors Programme started in 1999. The Food and Agriculture Organization is a part of the  United Nations.  The Ambassadors increase public awareness about hunger in the world. 

[[David di Donatello]]

CATEGORIES: Movie awards, Italian movies, 1955 establishments in Europe, 1950s establishments in Italy

The David di Donatello Award is a film award.  It is presented each year by L'accademia del Cinema Italiano (ACI). There are 24 categories as of 2006.

[[God's will]]

CATEGORIES: Theology

God's will, an idea in Abrahamic religions, is what God wants to happen. Christians, Jews and Muslims believe that they should do God's will. In the Bible, God's will is that all people will turn to him (repent) from their sins and live with him forever, in Heaven. Christians believe that in order to do this, they must accept Jesus, God's son, into their lives. Different Christians have different interpretations of what God's will is.

[[Rebel Wilson]]

CATEGORIES: Australian movie actors, Australian television actors, Australian comedians, Actors from Sydney, 1980 births, Living people

Rebel Melanie Elizabeth Wilson (born 2 March 1980) is an Australian Producer, Writer, Singer and Actress. Her many movies include Ghost Rider, Pitch Perfect and Bridesmaids. She played Kimberley Boubier in Super Fun Night. 

Rebel Wilson was born in Sydney, New South Wales. She lives in West Hollywood, California .

[[Marrella]]

CATEGORIES: Arthropods, Cambrian, Fossils

Marrella splendens is an arthropod known from the middle Cambrian Burgess Shale of British Columbia.  It is the most common animal in the Burgess Shale.

[[Lawrenceville School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in New Jersey, 1810 establishments in the United States, 19th-century establishments in New Jersey

Lawrenceville School is a boarding prep school in the U.S. state of New Jersey. It was started in 1810 by Isaac Van Arsdale Brown, as the Maidenhead Academy. Until 1987 it did not let girls be students. Tuition for boarding students coses $53,320 plus a medical fee of $755, a technology fee of $465, and tuition refund insurance costing $453.

[[Stowe School]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 establishments in England, Schools in Buckinghamshire

Stowe School is a private school in Stowe, Buckinghamshire in England. Fifteen percent of its students come from other countries. Famous people who went there include Richard Branson, Roger Hodgson, and George Monbiot. It is also a boarding school. Boarders pay £10,325 each term. When three or more children from the same family are at Stowe at the same time, the first and second children pay 10% less and the third pays 5% less.

[[Middlesex University]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s establishments in England, Universities in London, Middlesex

Middlesex University is a university in North London, England. It started in 1973/74 as Middlesex Polytechnic. It became a university in 1992. 

Its main campus is in Hendon. This is in Greater London, and within the historic county boundary of Middlesex.

The university has overseas campuses in Dubai since 2004, Mauritius since 2009, and Malta since 2013.

[[Felsted School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, Essex

Felsted School is a boarding school in Felsted, England. It is for girls and boys aged 4 to 18. Ofsted rated it 'outstanding' in June 2011. In 2013, 97% of students got 5 A*-C grades in their GCSE examinations.

[[Pate's Grammar School]]

CATEGORIES: 1574 establishments, Gloucestershire, Grammar schools in England, 16th century establishments in England, 1570s establishments in Europe

Pate's Grammar School is a grammar school in Gloucestershire, England. It was started in 1574 by Richard Pate. In 1986 Pate's Grammar School for Girls and Cheltenham Grammar School for Boys were put together. In 2013 The Times called it the fourth best secondary state school in the UK.

[[Elizabeth Garrett Anderson]]

CATEGORIES: 1836 births, 1917 deaths, English physicians

Elizabeth Garrett Anderson (9 June 1836 – 17 December 1917) was an English medical doctor and sister of Millicent Fawcett. She is known for being the first woman to qualify as a doctor and surgeon in Britain and for starting a medical school for women. She was also the first female mayor in Britain. She had three children She taught herself french to go to the University of Paris.

[[Colchester Royal Grammar School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, Essex, 1206 establishments in Europe, 13th century establishments in England

Colchester Royal Grammar School (CRGS) is a grammar school in Colchester. It was started by Master John and Joseph Elianore in 1206. Since 2006 it has had the best A-level results in the country every year. 100% of students get 5 A*-C GCSEs including English and Maths.

[[Vocaloid]]

CATEGORIES: Music software

Vocaloid is a music software that's used to make vocals for music. It was created by Yamaha, a company that sells musical instruments, as well as other products. The user can type in lyrics and a melody and it will synthesize singing. Voicebanks for Vocaloid are made by recording samples of singers.

Vocaloid was developed partially through a research project led by Kenmochi Hideki. The people involved in this project later created the company Voctro Labs. Vocaloid was originally not supposed to be a commercial product, but with the help of Yamaha, became the program we know today.

Vocaloid originally only had an English version available, with two English voicebanks, Leon and Lola, being released for it. This changed later on with the release of Kaito and Meiko, which were both Japanese voicebanks.

Vocaloid is meant both for professional and amateur music makers, since Vocaloid is easy to use, so the only limit is the user's skill. Music groups like Livetune and Supercell have made music using Vocaloid voicebanks.

[[The Holt School]]

CATEGORIES: 1930s establishments in England, Berkshire, Schools in England

The Holt School is a secondary school for girls  in Wokingham, Berkshire, England. It has over 1200 girls from ages 11-18. Boys are admitted to the sixth form. The school was founded in the 1930s. It is a specialized language and science college. It is in the top 200 highest achieving schools in GCSE, AS and A level exam results.

Ofsted judged the school to be 'outstanding' and the sixth form to be 'good'. In 2013 88.3% of students got 5 A*-Cs in their GCSEs.

[[Ofsted]]

CATEGORIES: Education in England, 1992 establishments in England, London

The Office for Standards in Education, Children's Services and Skills (Ofsted) inspects all state schools in England. It writes reports about how good they are. It is funded by the government. It is organised under the Education (Schools) Act 1992. Michael Wilshaw is the head. It hires Additional Inspectors (AI) who do most of the inspections. It also hires Her Majesty's Inspectors (HMI) who come to 6-7% of inspections.

Ofsted's main office is on Kingsway, in central London.

[[King Edward VII School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, Sheffield, 1905 establishments in England

King Edward VII School is a secondary school and language college in Sheffield, England started in 1905. It has a sixth form. This means that students can study there until the age of 18. 50% of sixth form students come from other schools in Sheffield.  It is named after King Edward VII of the United Kingdom. In 2013 Ofsted said that the school 'requires improvement'.

[[Seiðr]]

CATEGORIES: Magic (paranormal), Germanic mythology, Witchcraft

Seid or Seiðr  is an Old Norse word for a kind of sorcery which was practised in Norse society. It is connected with Norse religion. No one knows where seid came from. It was practiced less with the spread of Christianity in Scandinavia. The practice was recorded in Norse stories (sagas) found by archeologists. Many scholars say that seid was like shamanism.

Both male and female Scandinavians practiced this form of magic. By doing so, they were often persecuted by society because they brought a taboo on themselves.

In pre-Christian Norse mythology, seid was associated with the god Odin, their god of war, poetry and sorcery. It was also associated with the goddess Freyja, who was their goddess of love and fertility.

Today, followers of modern paganism adopted forms of magic that they called seid. Their practices have since been studied by many researchers in the field of pagan studies.

[[Triglyceride]]

CATEGORIES: Lipids

A triglyceride /traiGLIseraid/ is a type of ester that comes from glycerol and three fatty acids. Triglycerides are a type of lipid found in the blood. They help enable the movement of adipose fat and glucose from the liver. Triglycerides are the main molecules that make up vegetable oil and animal fats. They are also a major component of oils found on human skin (sebum). Too much triglycerides has been linked to a number of cardiovascular diseases.

[[Goetia]]

CATEGORIES: Occult, Magic (paranormal), Demons

Goetia is a practice which involves invoking ("calling") angels and demons. The word came from the 17th-century grimoire The Lesser Key of Solomon. It describes the calling of seventy-two demons. The book was edited by Aleister Crowley in 1904. It was then called The Book of the Goetia of Solomon the King.

The word comes from the γοητεία goēteia, meaning "charm".

[[Tyler Breeze]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, Canadian professional wrestlers, Sportspeople from Vancouver, WWE wrestlers

Mattias Clement (born January 19, 1988 in Vancouver, British Columbia) better known by his ring name Tyler Breeze, is a Canadian professional wrestler currently signed to WWE where competes on the RAW brand with tag team partner Fandango.

[[Nucleoplasm]]

CATEGORIES: Cell biology

Nucleoplasm is the contents of the cell nucleus. It is the protoplasm inside the nuclear membrane.

It includes 

The main role of the nucleoplasm is to keep the chromosomes  separate from the cell cytoplasm, and support the translating of DNA to RNA

[[Peada of Mercia]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth unknown, 650s deaths, Converts to Christianity, Kings and Queens of Mercia

Peada (died 656) was briefly the King of Mercia. From 653 he had been King of the Middle Angles. Peada was a pagan who accepted baptism in order to marry the daughter of Oswiu of Northumbria.

[[The Day Reagan Was Shot]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 movies, American television movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, Presidency of Ronald Reagan

The Day Reagan Was Shot is a 2001 historical television-movie. It was co-produced by Oliver Stone.

[[Kenneth Welsh]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Actors from Alberta, American movie actors, American television actors, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Entertainers from Edmonton

Kenneth Welsh, CM (born March 30, 1942 in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada) is a Canadian-American movie and television actor (sometimes credited as Ken Welsh). He is known for his roles in Twin Peaks and in The Aviator. He also appeared in The Day Reagan Was Shot and in The Day After Tomorrow.

[[Edwin Meese]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, United States Attorneys General, American lawyers, American educators, Businesspeople from Oakland, California, Politicians from Oakland, California, US Republican Party politicians

Edwin "Ed" Meese, III (born December 2, 1931) is an American attorney, law professor, and author.

[[William J. Casey]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 1987 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Directors of the Central Intelligence Agency, Spies, US Republican Party politicians, Politicians from New York City, Members of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission

William Joseph Casey (March 13, 1913 – May 6, 1987) was an American politician. He was the Director of Central Intelligence from 1981 to 1987 under Ronald Reagan. In this capacity he oversaw the entire United States Intelligence Community and personally directed the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).

Casey was born on March 13, 1913 in Elmhurst, Queens, New York. He studied at Fordham University and at Saint John's University, New York Casey died on May 6, 1987 from brain cancer in Roslyn Harbor, New York, aged 74.

[[Global city]]

CATEGORIES: Urban planning, Economic geography, Cities

Global city (or world city) is a city that is widely considered to be an important part of the world economy. Most studies recognise London and New York City as the two most important global cities.

[[Joel Murray]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Illinois

Joel Murray (born April 17, 1963 in Wilmette, Illinois) is an American actor. He starred many television shows including Grand, Love & War, and Dharma and Greg. He also performed in movies, including God Bless America, Monsters University and Killing Reagan. His brother is actor Bill Murray.

[[Brian Doyle-Murray]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Screenwriters from Illinois, Actors from Illinois, Comedians from Illinois, Writers from Illinois

Brian Doyle-Murray (born Brian Murray; October 31, 1945) is an American comedian, screenwriter, actor and voice actor.  He is the older brother of actor/comedian Bill Murray and the two have acted together in some movies. Murray appeared on Caddyshack, Scrooged, Ghostbusters II, The Razor's Edge and Groundhog Day.

[[Randy Newman]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, American movie score composers, American pianists, American singer-songwriters, Best Original Song Academy Award-winning songwriters, Emmy Award winners, Grammy Award winners, Jewish American musicians, Jewish atheists, Singers from Los Angeles, California, Singers from New Orleans, Louisiana, Musicians from Los Angeles, California, Musicians from New Orleans, Louisiana

Randall Stuart "Randy" Newman (born November 28, 1943) is an American singer-songwriter, arranger, composer, and pianist. Newman is known for his voice and for his composition works for the Disney Pictures/Pixar movies. He is of Jewish descent and a atheist.

[[Unforgiven (2000)]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 in professional wrestling, Sports in Philadelphia, WWE Unforgiven, 2000 in the United States, 20th century in Pennsylvania, 2000s in Philadelphia

Unforgiven (2000) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Federation (WWF). It was held on September 24, 2000 at the First Union Center in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It was the third Unforgiven event held by the WWF.  

[[Hundred Flowers Awards]]

CATEGORIES: Movie awards, Chinese movies, 1962 establishments in Asia, 20th century establishments in China

The People's Hundred Flower Award (大众电影百花奖) or Hundred Flowers Awards are movie awards in China.  They are like the Golden Globe Award.  

The awards were given in 1962 and 1963.  They stopped until 1980. Then the awards were given every year from 1980 to 2004.  Since 2004 the Hundred Flowers is awarded on even years.  The Golden Rooster Awards are given on odd years.

Beginning in 2006, Chinese-language films from Taiwan and Hong Kong are also allowed to win the awards.

[[Francisco Martínez Soria]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 births, 1982 deaths, Spanish actors

Francisco "Paco" Martínez Soria was a Spanish actor.

During the Spanish Civil War he left his work to be in theatre as an amateur actor.  He was part of the theatre company of Rafael López Somoza.  After 2 years he formed his own theatre company.  He also worked with director Ignacio F. Iquino in 12 films.

[[Unforgiven (1999)]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 in professional wrestling, Sports in Charlotte, North Carolina, WWE Unforgiven

Unforgiven (1999) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Federation (WWF). It was held on September 26, 1999 at the Charlotte Coliseum in Charlotte, North Carolina. It was the second Unforgiven event held by the WWF.  

[[Jean Gabin]]

CATEGORIES: 1904 births, 1976 deaths, French actors

Jean Gabin was a French actor.  He also sometimes was a singer. Gabin is considered one of the great stars of French cinema.  He was made a member of the Légion d'honneur. A museum in Mériel contains his story and features, his war and film memorabilia.

At the age of 19, Gabin received a small role in a Folies Bergère production. He continued acting until he joined the military.  After his military service he began acting again.  He became part of a troupe that toured South America.  After returning to France they worked at the Moulin Rouge.

Gabin gained notice and received roles in films.  He became popular after being in films directed by Julien Duvivier.  He had many offers to work in Hollywood. When Germany occupied France in World War II, he went to the United States.  While there he had a romance with actress Marlene Dietrich.  He was difficult to work with and did not have success with his career in Hollywood.

Jean Gabin joined General Charles de Gaulle's Free French Forces.  He earned the Médaille militaire and a Croix de guerre for his wartime service in North Africa. 

After the war Gabin returned to acting. For several years his films did not make much money. Then the 1954 film Touchez pas au grisbi (Don't Touch the Loot) was a very profitable international success. Over the next twenty years, Gabin made close to 50 more films.

[[Division of Scullin]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, 1968 establishments in Australia

The Division of Scullin is an Australian Electoral Division in the state of Victoria. It includes the northern suburbs of Epping, Lalor, Bundoora, Mill Park and Plenty.

The Division replaced the Division of Darebin in 1968. It was named after Rt Hon James Scullin, Prime Minister of Australia from 1929 to 1932.  

[[Division of Menzies]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, Victoria, Australia, 1984 establishments in Australia

The Division of Menzies is an Australian Electoral Division in the state of Victoria. It is covers the suburbs of Bulleen, Croydon Hills, Doncaster, Doncaster East, Donvale, Park Orchards, Templestowe, Templestowe Lower, Warrandyte and Warrandyte South. There are also parts of Ringwood North, Warranwood and Wonga Park in the Division.

The Division was set up in 1984. It was named after Rt Hon Sir Robert Menzies, the longest serving Prime Minister of Australia. 

[[Brearley School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in New York, Buildings and structures in Manhattan, 1884 establishments in the United States, 1880s establishments in New York (state)

The Brearley School is an all-girls private school in New York City. It was started by Samuel A. Brearley in 1884. It costs $39,900 a term. Famous women who went there include Dorothy Schiff, Erica Wagner, Sara Moulton, and Virginia Gildersleeve.

[[Highclare School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, Birmingham, 1932 establishments in the United Kingdom, 1930s establishments in England

Highclare School is a private school in Birmingham, England. It teaches mostly girls and some boys aged 18 months to 18 years. It was started in 1932. It has three buildings in different areas of Sutton Coldfield and Erdington. They have a 100% pass rate at GCSE.

[[Naropa University]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in Colorado, 1974 establishments in the United States, 1970s establishments in Colorado

Naropa University is a private liberal arts college in Colorado. It was started in 1974 by Chögyam Trungpa. It is named after Naropa, a Buddhist Mahasiddha who lived in the eleventh century. It has three campuses: Araphoe, Paramita, and Nalanda.

[[City of London School for Girls]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in London, 1894 establishments in the United Kingdom

City of London School for Girls (CLSG) is a private school for girls aged 7-18 in London, England. It was started by William Ward in 1894.

It is associated with the City of London School (a boys day school) and the City of London Freemen's School (a boys and girls day and boarding school).

97% of A Level results are A*-B grades. Over 50% study Maths at A Level. 30% get into Oxford or Cambridge. Famous women who went there include Dido, Tasmin Lucia-Khan, Hermione Lee, and Romola Garai. Charlotte Barbour-Condini is currently a student, who was a finalist for BBC, Young Musician of the Year, on 2012.

[[C. W. Alcock]]

CATEGORIES: 1842 births, 1907 deaths, People from Sunderland, Association football, English footballers, English cricketers

Charles William Alcock (2 December 1842 – 26 February 1907) was an English sportsperson. He was important in the development of both international football and cricket. He was also the creator of the FA Cup. He went to Harrow School. He married Eliza Caroline and they had two sons and six daughters.

[[Brighton College]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, Brighton, 1845 establishments in Europe, 1840s establishments in England

Brighton College is a boarding school in Brighton, England. It is for boys and girls aged between 3 and 18. Richard Cairns is headmaster. It was started by William Aldwin Soames in 1845. It is a charity school.

[[Women in Ancient Greece]]

CATEGORIES: Ancient Greece, Women

The status of women in Classical Greece was different in different city states. Women in ancient Delphi, Gortyn, Thessaly, Megara and Sparta could own land, which was the most prestigious form of private property at the time.

[[Rabbit-Proof Fence (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: Australian drama movies, 2002 drama movies, Movies set in the 1930s, Movies set in Australia, Movies set in deserts, Movies directed by Phillip Noyce

Rabbit-Proof Fence is an Australian drama movie. It was directed by Phillip Noyce in 2002 for 6 million US dollars.

[[Marlborough College]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, Wiltshire, 1843 establishments in Europe, 1840s establishments in England

Marlborough College is a secondary boarding school in Marlborough, Wiltshire, England. It was started in 1843 for sons of the leaders of the Church of England. It now accepts boys and girls of all religious beliefs, but is classed as a Church of England school. It has a chapel where there is Eucharist every Sunday. It is a member of the G20 Schools Group. It costs £32,280 a year.

[[Lancing College]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, West Sussex

Lancing College is a private boarding school in Lancing, England for girls and boys aged 13 to 18. Important people who went there include Charles Wollaston, Sir Roy Calne, and Alex Horne. It costs £31,240 a year for boarders.

[[Institut Le Rosey]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in Switzerland, 1880 establishments in Europe

Institut Le Rosey, commonly known simply as Le Rosey, is a boarding school in Rolle, Switzerland. It has ~400 students aged 7 to 18. 

It was started by Paul-Émile Carnal in 1880 and is Switzerland's oldest private school. Royalty from around the world have been students. No more than 10% of the students come from any one country. Students applying to be seniors must be able to work in English and French. Fees: ~ $136,000 per annum.

This is a school for the rich international set. Before the introduction of the 10% quota (where no more than 10% of the student body may come from one country) different nationalities made up the majority of students at Le Rosey. 

In the 1950s and 1960s, most students were Americans, Italians, and Greeks. In the 1970s came the Arabs and Iranians. In the 1980s came Japanese and Koreans, and in the 1990s came the Russians. During the 1990s, came the children of Russian oligarchs, who made up a third of the student body. They "terrorized" other students, which resulted in the withdrawal of at least one non-Russian student.

Since then, quotas have been applied.

[[Gstaad International School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in Switzerland, 1962 establishments in Europe, 20th century establishments in Switzerland

Gstaad International School is a private preparatory boarding school in Switzerland. It was started in 1962.

[[Collège Alpin International Beau Soleil]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in Switzerland, 1910 establishments in Europe

Collège Alpin International Beau Soleil is a private school in Switzerland. It started in 1910. It is located in Villars-sur-Ollon, in Vaud. It is the second most expensive school in the world. It costs CHF 93,000 a year to be a student.

[[Trinity-Pawling School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in New York, 1907 establishments in the United States, 1900s establishments in New York (state)

Trinity-Pawling School is an all-boys private boarding high school. It is in Pawling, New York. Trinity-Pawling was started in 1907, by Frederick Luther Gamage. The cost to attend is $51,000 a year.

[[Groton School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in Massachusetts, 1884 establishments in the United States, 19th-century establishments in Massachusetts

Groton School is a preparatory boarding school in Massachusetts. It was started in 1884 by the Rev. Endicott Peabody. It gives free education to students with household incomes below $75,000 a year. It has a chapel, St. John's Chapel. It has 270 students. Boarders pay $53,870 a year.

[[Forman School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in Connecticut, 1930 establishments in the United States, 20th-century establishments in Connecticut

Forman School is a boarding school in Connecticut for students with learning disabilities. It was founded in 1930 by John and Julie Ripley Forman.

[[Wellington College]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in Berkshire, 1859 establishments in the United Kingdom, 1850s establishments in England

Wellington College is a secondary boarding school in Berkshire, South East England for girls and boys. It was started by Queen Victoria in 1859. It is a member of the Rugby Group and the G20 Schools group. 

In 2006 it became the first school to have happiness lessons. The headmaster is James Dahl. 10% of students get into Cambridge or Oxford University.

[[C-SPAN]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 establishments in the United States, American television channels, Cable television

C-SPAN (ˈ; an acronym for Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network) is a private, not-for-profit cable television network in the United States. It was created in 1979 by the cable television industry as a public service. It televises many proceedings of the U.S. federal government, as well as other programs related to public affairs.

[[Bahá'í calendar]]

CATEGORIES: Calendars, Bahá'í Faith, Babism

The Bahá'í calendar, named the Badí‘ calendar (badí‘ means wondrous or unique), is a solar calendar used by Bábism and the Bahá'í Faith. 

The calendar was created by the Báb and refined by Bahá'u'lláh and the Universal House of Justice. 

Each year starts on "Naw-Rúz", the vernal equinox (in March), and has 19 months. Each month has 19 days. An extra 4 or 5 days are added between the last two months so that the next year also starts on the equinox. Each day begins at sunset. The time of sunset and the time of the equinox are calculated by astronomers. 

The months are known by their Arabic names. The days within each month also use the same names. Here they are with their usual English translations:

Each group of 19 years is called a Váhid. 

Each group of 19 Váhids is called a Kull-i-Shay’.

Year 1 of the Badí' calendar started at Naw-Rúz in 1844 A.D.

[[Gertrude B. Elion]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 1999 deaths, American biochemists, Pharmacologists, Female scientists, Scientists from New York City, American Nobel Prize winners

Gertrude Belle Elion (January 23, 1918 – February 21, 1999) was an American biochemist and pharmacologist. In 1988, she received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine along with Sir James Black, a British coworker.

[[Haldan Keffer Hartline]]

CATEGORIES: 1903 births, 1983 deaths, Physiologists, Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine winners, American Nobel Prize winners, Scientists from Pennsylvania

Haldan Keffer Hartline ForMemRS (December 22, 1903 – March 17, 1983) was an American physiologist. He was a co-winner (with George Wald and Ragnar Granit) of the 1967 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his work in analyzing the neurophysiological mechanisms of vision.

[[Stephanie Adams]]

CATEGORIES: Writers from New York, 1970 births, 2018 deaths, Suicides by jumping in the United States, Writers from New Jersey, Models from New Jersey, People from Orange, New Jersey

Stephanie Adams (July 24, 1970 – May 18, 2018) was an American author. She was a model and was Playboy Playmate for November 1992. Orange, New Jersey was her birth place but Adams grew up in New York. She was raised by two of her aunts Joyce and Pearl, former models who encouraged Adams to do modeling when she was 16.

Adams committed suicide with her 7 year-old son by jumping off a balcony in New York City on May 18, 2018 at the age of 47.

[[Non-coding RNA]]

CATEGORIES: RNA

A non-coding RNA (ncRNA) is a functional RNA molecule which is not translated into a protein. Less-used synonyms are non-protein-coding RNA (npcRNA), non-messenger RNA (nmRNA) and functional RNA (fRNA). The term small RNA (sRNA) is often used for short bacterial ncRNAs. The DNA sequence from which a non-coding RNA is transcribed is often called an 'RNA gene'.

Non-coding RNA genes include abundant and important RNAs such as transfer RNA (tRNA) and ribosomal RNA (rRNA); also RNAs such as snoRNAs, microRNAs, siRNAs, snRNAs, exRNAs, and piRNAs and the long noncoding RNAs (long ncRNAs). The number of ncRNAs in the human genome is unknown. However recent studies suggest the existence of thousands of ncRNAs., but see  Since the function of newly identified ncRNAs has not been proved, it is possible that many are non-functional.

The first non-coding RNA to be analysed was an alanine tRNA found in baker's yeast. Its structure was published in 1965.

[[City Montessori School]]

CATEGORIES: Uttar Pradesh, Schools in India, 1959 establishments in Asia, 1950s establishments in India

City Montessori School is a private school in Lucknow, India. It was started in 1959 by Bharti Gandhi and Jagdish Gandhi. It had five pupils. It now has the most students of any school in the world. It has twenty campuses.

[[WrestleMania X8]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 in professional wrestling, Sport in Toronto, WrestleMania, 2000s in Canada, 21st century in Toronto

WrestleMania X8 was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Federation (WWF). It was held on March 17, 2002 at the SkyDome in Toronto, Ontario. It was the eighteenth WrestleMania event held by the WWF and was the second WrestleMania to take place in Toronto with the first being WrestleMania VI in 1990. This was the final WrestleMania under WWF name.

[[Handicap principle]]

CATEGORIES: Animal communication, Evolution

The handicap principle was invented by Prof. Amotz Zahavi from Tel Aviv University. It claims to explain the fact that some animals have characteristics that do not necessarily help them survive. Let's take the peacock for example. The peacock's tail is long and heavy and actually diminishes its chances to survive. So why did it evolutionarily survive? According to the principle, one day, a mutant peahen that likes peacocks with longer tail, looked for a male with this characteristic. The mature male she found was strong enough to survive even though it had a long tail and therefore it is probably stronger than the average peacock. Therefore, its predecessor males are going to be stronger and also to have a long tail while the newborn females are going to like long tails, passing the ideals of the principle to the next generations.

This principle comes in addition to the well-known adaptation part of evolution theory claiming that the one who fits best to its environment survives.

[[Flame-throated bulbul]]

CATEGORIES: Birds of India, Passeri

The flame-throated bulbul (Rubigula gularis) is a bird found in south western India. It eats fruit and insects, and lives in thick bushes and trees. It is a part of the bulbul family of birds and is yellow with a black head and red neck.

[[Bulbul]]

CATEGORIES: Passeri

[[Wolseley Expedition]]

CATEGORIES: 1870, History of Canada

The Wolseley Expedition was a military force put together to capture the Canadian Métis leader Louis Riel. It was led by Colonel Garnet Wolsely. The expedition took place in 1870 and went from Toronto to Winnipeg. Because of the fact that the expedition had to carry so much equipment and guns, the Wolsely Expedition is thought to be one of the most difficult in all of recent history.

[[Bert Diaries]]

CATEGORIES: Children's literature

The Bert Diaries are a series of novels written in the form of a diary. They are by Swedish writers Anders Jacobsson and Sören Olsson. The main character is a teenager named Bert Ljung. Ljung lives in Öreskoga, a fictional town in Sweden, in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The first book was published in 1987. Bert and his friends also have a pop/rock band, the Heman Hunters.

A TV series was made in 1994. It is directed by Tomas Alfredson and Svante Kettner. It was followed by a movie in 1995, also directed by Alfredson. In late-July 2016 the recording of a new Bert film was announced.

Between 1993 and 2002, and comic book, FF med Bert, was published Between 1992 and 1999, comic albums were published.

[[Sune (book series)]]

CATEGORIES: Children's literature

The Sune series is a series of children's/youth books by Swedish writers Anders Jacobsson and Sören Olsson. The books have been published since 1984. The stories are originally a radio series, produced as totally 90 episodes for Swedish radio between the years of 1983 and 1993. The Sune books are set in fictional town of Glimmerdagg in Sweden, which just like Berts hometown Öreskoga is located somewhere between Karlskoga-Örebro. There is Söderskolan, for the grades 1–6. The Sune books are told in the third person perspective and using the present tense and uses imperfect during flashback scenes, while Bert is told as a first person narrative.

Instead of being a typical "tough guy" who uses to fight or play soccer, Sune is more interested into girls.

[[The Kane Chronicles]]

CATEGORIES: Rick Riordan, Series of books, Fantasy books

The Kane Chronicles are a series of fantasy novels by Rick Riordan. The characters are based on Egyptian mythology. The story is set in the same universe as Riordan's Percy Jackson & the Olympians, The Heroes of Olympus, The Trials of Apollo, and Magnus Chase and the Gods of Asgard series.

[[Jean Marais]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 1998 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in France, French LGBT people, French movie actors, French television actors, LGBT actors

Jean-Alfred Villain-Marais was a French actor and director. Marais had over 100 roles in film and on television. He was also known for writing, painting and sculpture.

In the 1950s, Marais became a star of swashbuckling films. He performed his own stunts.  After 1970 he mostly worked in plays.

Jean-Paul Belmondo (9 April 1933 – 6 September 2021) was a French actor. He was popular during the New Wave of the 1960s.

[[Kana Hanazawa]]

Kana Hanazawa is a voice actress of anime characters. She is also an actress and a singer. She works for the Office Osawa talent agency. In Japan, she is known for voicing many anime characters.

Hoshizora☆Destination, was released in 25 April 2012. It was her first single.

[[GD 61]]

CATEGORIES: Stars

GD 61 is a white dwarf star. It is 150 light-years from Earth in the constellation Perseus.

An asteroid in the system was detected in 2013 that contains water. This was the first finding of solid or liquid water on an extrasolar body. The asteroid, the first extrasolar asteroid detected, is 26% water by mass, close to the water content of Ceres. This means that a planet, with a rocky surface similar to Earth's, may have existed in the past. The asteroid could be an artifact from this period. It is now possibly part of a debris field from that planet's breakup. Such a planet would have had both a rocky surface and water. These are two key ingredients for life. The researchers used the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph on the Hubble Space Telescope to determine what it is made of. The elements magnesium, silicon, iron and oxygen were detected. These are all components of rocky planets. However, the amount of oxygen is much higher than what was expected. There was also less carbon than expected. This meant there was one possible reason for the extra oxygen. There had to be water there.

[[Pilgrim of Eternity]]

CATEGORIES: Star Trek, 2013 in entertainment

"Pilgrim of Eternity" is an episode of Star Trek that was created by fans. It was released in 2013. It is the first in a planned web series, Star Trek Continues. It is a sequel to the original series episode, "Who Mourns for Adonais?".

[[Cat Power]]

CATEGORIES: American singer-songwriters, 1972 births, Living people, Singers from Atlanta, Georgia

Charlyn Marie Marshall (better known by her stage identity Cat Power; 21 January, 1972) is an American singer-songwriter and musician. She has been releasing albums since 1992. Her cover of "Sea of Love" is played in the 2007 movie Juno.

Her album Sun, released in 2012, is her best and highest-charting record as of 2013. 

She was born in Atlanta, and has lived in several other states.

[[Alternator]]

CATEGORIES: Electricity, Machines

An alternator is a generator which converts mechanical energy to electrical energy in the form of alternating current. There is one in every car.

Most alternators use a rotating magnetic field with a stationary armature. The armature reacts to the rotating field and carries the current caused by the rotation. 

In principle, any AC electrical generator can be called an alternator, but usually the term refers to small rotating machines driven by automotive and other internal combustion engines. 

An alternator that uses a permanent magnet for its magnetic field is called a magneto. Alternators in power stations driven by steam turbines are called turbo-alternators.

[[Capacitance]]

CATEGORIES: Electricity

Capacitance is the ability of a body to store electric charge.  A common device to do such task is a capacitor. The SI unit for capacitance is farad.

Where Q is the charge in the object and V is voltage across that object.

[[Division of Cook]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1969 establishments in Australia

The Division of Cook is an Australian Electoral Division in New South Wales. It was set up in 1969 and is named for James Cook, who mapped the east coast of Australia in 1770. It is located in the southern suburbs of Sydney, including Caringbah, Cronulla, Miranda and Sylvania. 

[[Nieuport 11]]

CATEGORIES: French military aircraft, World War I aircraft

The Nieuport 11 is a French single-engine biplane fighter aircraft used during World War I that allowed France to defeat the German Fokker Eindeckers. 

It sometimes called "Bébé" (the French word for baby) due to its small size.

A more powerful version, the Nieuport 16 was also built, leading to a series of fighters that served into the 1920s.

[[Columbia Business School]]

CATEGORIES: Ivy League, Schools in New York, 1916 establishments in the United States, Buildings and structures in Manhattan, 1910s establishments in New York (state)

Columbia Business School (CBS) is a business school of Columbia University in Manhattan, New York City. It was established in 1916. Its purpose is to provide training and professional preparation for undergraduate and graduate Columbia University students. It is one of six Ivy League business schools. Its admission process is among the most selective of top schools.

[[University of Nebraska–Lincoln]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska, 1869 establishments in the United States, 1860s establishments in Nebraska

The University of Nebraska–Lincoln (also called Nebraska, UNL or NU) it is a public university that also does research. It is located in Lincoln, Nebraska, USA. UNL is the state's oldest and largest university campus. It is also the leading school in the University of Nebraska system.

[[Nilo-Saharan languages]]

CATEGORIES: Languages of Africa

The Nilo-Saharan languages are a family of African languages. They are spoken by around 50 million people, who mainly live in the upper parts of the Chari and Nile rivers. The languages go through 17 countries in the northern half of Africa: from Algeria to Benin in the west; from Libya to the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the center; and from Egypt to Tanzania in the east.

[[Herman Kahn]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 1983 deaths, American atheists, American Jews, American mathematicians, People from Bayonne, New Jersey

Herman Kahn (February 15, 1922 – July 7, 1983) was one of the preeminent futurists of the second half of the twentieth century. His theories helped to develop the nuclear strategy of the United States.

[[Backlash (2002)]]

This was the first time a WWF pay-per-view was held at Kemper Arena since WWF Over The Edge 1999 where Owen Hart, competing as the Blue Blazer at the time, lost his life after he fell 78 feet from a harness to the ring during an entrance stunt and landed chest-first on the top rope, approximately a foot from the nearest turnbuckle.

[[Pekwachnamaykoskwaskwaypinwanik Lake]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of Canada, Manitoba

Pekwachnamaykoskwaskwaypinwanik Lake is a fresh water lake in Manitoba, Canada. It is Cree for "where the wild trout are caught by fishing with hooks." It is the longest place name in Canada. It is located near Red Sucker Lake in northeastern Manitoba.

[[Wimbledon High School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in London, 1880 establishments in the United Kingdom

Wimbledon High School is a private school for girls aged 4-18 in Wimbledon in South West London. It was started in 1880 by The Girls' Day School Trust.

[[Division of Cunningham]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1949 establishments in Australia

The Division of Cunningham is an Australian electoral division in New South Wales. It was set up in 1949 and is named for Allan Cunningham, a 19th century explorer of New South Wales and Queensland.

It is on the coast of New South Wales and includes parts of the city of Wollongong, Corrimal, Figtree and Unanderra. It also includes several suburbs of Sydney, including Heathcote and Bundeena. 

[[Maltby Academy]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, 1931 establishments, South Yorkshire, 1930s establishments in England

Maltby Academy is a secondary school in Maltby, England. It started as Maltby Grammar School in 1931. In 1967 it became Maltby Comprehensive School. In 2010 it became an academy and changed its name to reflect this.

Yarm School is a private school in Yarm, England for girls and boys 3-18. It started as Yarm Grammar School in 1590.

[[Aircraft Apprentice Scheme]]

CATEGORIES: Royal Air Force, 1920 establishments in the United Kingdom, 1966 disestablishments, 1960s disestablishments in the United Kingdom

The Aircraft Apprentice Scheme was a training programme in the Royal Air Force. It lasted from 1920 to 1966. The training programme was for aircraft ground crew (those who servicing the aircraft on the ground, as opposed to the pilots).

The Apprentice Scheme was the result of the Royal Air Force's decision to open Schools of Technical Training. RAF Halton was chosen as the home for the training of men and boys. The School of Technical Training (for boys) was not formed as a separate unit until 1919 and only became a permanent establishment on 1 January 1920. In March of that year, RAF Halton was named No. 1 School of Technical Training. No. 2 School of Technical Training at RAF Cranwell was created because there was not enough accommodation to house the boys at RAF Halton.

[[2 Chainz]]

CATEGORIES: American rap musicians from Georgia, Musicians from Georgia (U.S. state), 1977 births, Living people, Gangsta rappers, African-American rappers

Tauheed Epps (born September 12, 1977), known professionally as 2 Chainz (formerly Tity Boi), is an American rapper. He was born in College Park, Georgia. He is best known for his singles "Riot", "No Lie" (featuring Drake), "I'm Different" and "Birthday Song". He is also known for being half the duo of the rap group Playaz Circle along with rapper and long time friend Dolla Boy. The group was discovered by fellow rapper Ludacris and signed them to his Record Label DTP. 2 Chainz gained recognition as a solo artist when he was featured on Kanye West's 2012 single "Mercy" off his album Cruel Summer. He has 2 albums: Based On A True Story  and his most recent one B.O.A.T.S: Me Time.

[[Division of Dobell]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1984 establishments in Australia

The Division of Dobell is an Australian electoral Division in New South Wales.  It was set up in 1984 and is named for the Australian painter, Sir William Dobell. It is on the Central Coast and includes Bateau Bay, Berkeley Vale, Blue Haven, The Entrance, Gorokan, Jilliby, Ourimbah, Toukley, Tuggerah, Tumbi Umbi, Wamberal, Wyoming.

[[Nick Cardy]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2013 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, American comics writers, American comics artists, Writers from New York City

Nicholas Viscardi (October 20, 1920 – November 3, 2013), known professionally as Nick Cardy or Nick Cardi, was American comic book artist. He is best known for his DC Comics work on Aquaman, the Teen Titans and other major characters. Cardy was inducted into the Will Eisner Comic Book Hall of Fame in 2005.

Cardy was born on October 20, 1920 in New York City, New York. He studied at the Art Students League of New York, studying life drawing. Cardy was married to Ruth Houghby from 1947 until they divorced in 1969. They had one son. Cardy died on November 3, 2013 from heart failure at his Miami, Florida home, aged 93.

[[Hal Needham]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2013 deaths, Deaths from cancer, American movie actors, American television actors, Stuntmen, Writers from Tennessee, Actors from Memphis, Tennessee, People from Little Rock, Arkansas, Actors from Arkansas, Actors from St. Louis, Missouri, Movie directors from Missouri

Hal Brett Needham (March 6, 1931 – October 25, 2013) was an American stuntman, movie director, actor, and writer. He is known for directing the 1971 comedy movie Smokey and the Bandit and The Cannonball Run. Needham received the Taurus World Stunt Awards Lifetime Achievement Award. 

Needham was born on March 6, 1931 in Memphis, Tennessee. He was raised in Little Rock, Arkansas and in St. Louis, Missouri. 

Needham was married to Dani Crayne from 1981 until they divorced in 1996. Then he was married to Ellyn Wynne Williams from 1996 until his death in 2013. Needham died on October 25, 2013 from cancer in Los Angeles, California, aged 82.

[[Juan Carlos Calabró]]

Juan Carlos Calabró (3 February 1934 – 5 November 2013) was an Argentine actor and comedian. He was known for his work Johnny Tolengo, el majestuoso.

Calabró was born on 3 February 1934 in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Calabró died on 5 November 2013 in Buenos Aires, Argentina from kidney disease, aged 79.

[[Mr. Morgan's Last Love]]

CATEGORIES: 2013 comedy-drama movies, German drama movies, Belgian movies, American comedy-drama movies, French comedy movies, French drama movies

Mr. Morgan's Last Love is an 2013 comedy-drama movie based on Francoise Dorner's French novel La Douceur Assassine. It is written and directed by Sandra Nettelbeck. It stars Michael Caine and Clémence Poésy. It was released to negative reviews on November 1, 2013.

[[Life of Pi (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 drama movies, 2010s adventure movies, American adventure movies, American drama movies, British adventure movies, British drama movies, Taiwanese movies, Canadian drama movies, Mexican movies, French drama movies, Indian movies, English-language movies, Survival movies, Movies directed by Ang Lee

Life of Pi is a 2012 American drama movie produced and directed by Ang Lee. It stars Suraj Sharma. It was released to very positive reviews on November 21, 2012. It was nominated for three Golden Globe Awards, including Best Picture - Drama and Best Director, and won for Best Original Score. At the 85th Academy Awards, it had 11 nominations, including Best Picture and Best Adapted Screenplay, and won four (the most of the night), including Best Director for Ang Lee.

[[Judgment Day (2008)]]

[[Division of Eden-Monaro]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1901 establishments in Australia

The Division of Eden-Monaro is an Australian electoral division in New South Wales. It was one of the 75 divisions set up for the first federal election in 1901. It is named for the town of Eden and the Monaro district of southern New South Wales. It includes Batemans Bay, Bega, Cooma and Queanbeyan. 

Since 1972 the Division has always been won the party that wins government in the elections. It is closely watched by the media when trying to pick the results of an election.

[[Graham Stark]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2013 deaths, Actors from Cheshire, Cardiovascular disease deaths in England, Deaths from stroke, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, English radio actors, Writers from Cheshire

Graham William Stark (20 January 1922 – 29 October 2013) was an English comedian, actor, writer and director. He was known for his roles in Alfie and in Superman III. 

Stark was born on 20 January 1922 in Wallasey, Cheshire, England. He studied at Wallasey Grammar School. Stark began acting when he was 13 years old. 

Stark was also an accomplished stills photographer. Stark died in London on 29 October 2013 after suffering a stroke. He was 91.

[[Hans von Borsody]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2013 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Austrian movie actors, Austrian television actors, Austrian stage actors, German movie actors, German television actors, German stage actors, Actors from Vienna

Hans von Borsody (20 September 1929 – 4 November 2013) was a German-Austrian actor. 

He was born in Vienna as a member of an artists family. His father Eduard von Borsody was a movie director, his uncle Julius von Borsody a set designer. His daughter Suzanne von Borsody is also an actress.

von Borsody died on 4 November 2013 in Berlin, Germany from lung cancer, aged 84.

[[Division of Farrer]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1949 establishments in Australia

The Division of Farrer is an Australian Electoral Division in New South Wales. It was set up in 1949 and is named for William Farrer, an agricultural scientist. It is in the southern rural area of the state and includes Albury, Balranald, Broken Hill, Deniliquin and Jerilderie.

[[Jorge Ramos]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, Television news anchors, Mexican journalists, Writers from Mexico City, Emmy Award winners

Jorge Ramos Ávalos (born March 16, 1958) is a Mexican journalist for Univision. He is the anchor for Noticiero Univision and host of the Sunday morning news talk show Al Punto. Also, on Fusion TV, he hosts America with Jorge Ramos, which debuted on October 29, 2013.

Ramos was born on March 16, 1958 in Mexico City, Mexico. He studied at Universidad Iberoamericana. Ramos has won eight Emmy Awards throughout his career for journalism.

[[Judgment Day (2007)]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 in professional wrestling, Sports in St. Louis, Missouri, WWE Judgment Day, 2007 in the United States, 2000s in Missouri, History of St. Louis, Missouri

Judgment Day (2007) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view show made by World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). It was held on May 20, 2007 at the Scottrade Center in St. Louis, Missouri. It was the ninth Judgment Day event held by the WWE.

[[Christian (given name)]]

CATEGORIES: Given names

Christian is a given name. Both men and women can be named "Christian". The name comes from the Latin word Christianus, meaning "follower of Christ". It has been commonly used as a name since the Middle Ages - especially amongst females.

The name is popular in Europe, United States and other English-speaking countries. In Europe — though not the United States — it is almost exclusively used as a male name. However, in the 17th and 18th centuries it was a popular female first name in Scotland.February 2011

Female variants of the name include Christine, Christina, Christiane, Kristen, Kristin, and Kirsten.  Holders of the name Christian may go by the nicknames or shortened forms Chris, Chrissy, Crix or Xian.

[[Enhanced geothermal system]]

CATEGORIES: Geothermal energy, Power plants

An enhanced geothermal system (EGS) is a geothermal energy system that can make electrical energy when natural underground water is not there. For a long time, geothermal energy could only be produced when there were hot rocks, underground water, and cracks in rocks all together in one area. Now, new ways of getting this power source are being created. Areas that can possibly be used for energy need to be altered by people to make the energy usable. These areas may need either underground water and/or cracks, or fracture network, in rocks. Enhanced geothermal systems allow for geothermal energy to be outside normal geothermal areas like active plate boundaries to less active areas like the western United States.

[[Division of Fowler]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1984 establishments in Australia

The Division of Fowler is an Australian Electoral Division in New South Wales. It was set up in 1984 and named after Lilian Fowler, the first woman mayor in Australia. It includes the suburbs of Ashcroft, Austral, Bonnyrigg, Bonnyrigg Heights, Busby, Cabramatta, Cabramatta West, Canley Heights, Canley Vale, Cartwright, Cecil Hills, Cecil Park, Edensor Park, Green Valley, Greenfield Park, Heckenberg, Hinchinbrook, Lansvale, Liverpool, Middleton Grange, Miller, Mount Pritchard, Prairiewood, Sadleir, St Johns Park, Wakeley and West Hoxton.

[[The Latymer School]]

CATEGORIES: 1624 establishments, Grammar schools in England, Schools in London, 17th century establishments in England, 1620s establishments in Europe

The Latymer School is a grammar school in Edmonton, London, England. It was started in 1624 by merchant Edward Latymer. In their 2008 report Ofsted graded the school as 'outstanding'. Bruce Forsyth was a student. The school is selective and co-educational.

About 186 pupils are admitted to Year 7 (aged 11 or 12) annually. Places are awarded by a competitive examination. 20 places are reserved for pupils with exceptional musical talent. The examinations taken by prospective pupils cover non-verbal reasoning, verbal reasoning and numeracy.

Around 60-70 pupils join the sixth form in Year 12 (aged 16 or 17) per year, mixing with Latymer pupils who have made the transition from Year 11. External applicants to the sixth form sit entrance examinations and generally require 6 A grades at GCSE (or equivalent) level.

[[Boeing T-43]]

CATEGORIES: Boeing 737, United States Air Force aircraft

The Boeing T-43 is a military variant of the twin-turbojet airliner Boeing 737-200. It was used between 1973 and 2010 as a training aircraft by the US Air Force. It was the biggest training aircraft in the United States.

It was used by Air Education and Training Command's 12th Flying Training Wing. Some were built as CT-43 for passenger transport duties.

[[Haberdashers' Aske's School for Girls]]

CATEGORIES: 1875 establishments in England, Schools in Hertfordshire

Haberdashers' Aske's School for Girls is a private school for girls in Elstree, Hertfordshire. It was started in 1875 by the Worshipful Company of Haberdashers. In 2013 100% of GCSEs were A*-C and 69.8% were A*.

[[Elstree]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Hertfordshire

Elstree is a village in Hertfordshire, England. The television show EastEnders is made there at Elstree Studios.

[[Emmerdale]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 television series debuts, 1970s British television series, 1980s British drama television series, 1990s British drama television series, 2000s British drama television series, 2010s British drama television series, British soap operas, Television shows set in Yorkshire, English-language television programs

Emmerdale is a British soap opera. It is set in a made-up village called Emmerdale, called Beckindale until 1994, in the Yorkshire Dales. The plot is focused on things that happen in and around The Woolpack, the main village pub. It is on ITV every weekday at 7 o'clock. It was called Emmerdale Farm until 1989. It was started in 1972 by Kevin Laffan, making it Britain's second oldest soap opera after Coronation Street. It is one of the most popular television programmes in Britain. It has been given many awards including one BAFTA.

[[Rockwell B-1 Lancer]]

CATEGORIES: United States Air Force aircraft

The Rockwell B-1 Lancer is a strategic bomber in the service of the US Air Force. It is a four-turbojet aircraft that uses a variable-sweep wing. It can carry nuclear weapons or classic bombs. It is only used by the USA.

== Variants == 

[[History of modern Mongolia]]

CATEGORIES: History of Mongolia

Mongolia became independent on December 29, 1911 from the Qing Dynasty.

[[Fiat G.50]]

CATEGORIES: Italian military aircraft, World War II aircraft

The Fiat G.50 was an Italian fighter aircraft. It was used for World War II. It was a single-engine aircraft with a single seat. It carried were two 0.50 machine-guns as weapons. Countries that operated this aircraft were Croatia, Finland, Italy, Nazi Germany, Spain, and Yugoslavia.

[[Mers-les-Bains]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Somme

Mers-les-Bains is a commune of Somme near Eu and Le Tréport. By the river Bresles, it marks the border with Upper Normandy. This commune is famous for its beach and its casino.

[[The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano]]

CATEGORIES: 1780s books, American novels, 1789 works, Autobiographies

The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano, or Gustavus Vassa, The African, is a book that was first published in 1789. It is the autobiography of Olaudah Equiano. The book describes Equiano's life in slavery. It records his efforts to be free by studying the Bible. The book goes on to tell about his gaining his freedom and his success in business. It was published in 1789 in Great Britain to inform the British public what the life of slaves was like.

[[Bridgewater High School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, 1987 establishments in England, Cheshire

Bridgewater High School is a secondary school in Warrington, Cheshire, England. It started in 1987. It was rated 'outstanding' by Ofsted. It has a sixth form called Appleton College.

[[King Solomon High School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in London, 1993 establishments in Europe

King Solomon High School is a secondary school in Barkingside, England. In their 2010 report Osted described the school as 'caring'.

[[Colyton Grammar School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, 1546 establishments in England, Devon

Colyton Grammar School is a grammar school in the village of Colyford in England. It was started in 1546. 49.4% of GCSEs in 2013 were A*, an increase of 4% on the past year, and 68.5% of A-levels were A*-A. Ofsted rated the school as outstanding.

[[Division of Gilmore]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1984 establishments in Australia

The Division of Gilmore is an Australian Electoral Division in New South Wales. It was set up in 1984 and is named for Dame Mary Gilmore, the poet and author. It includes the Budawang and Morton National Parks.  The division includes Berry, Bomaderry, Culburra Beach, Gerringong, Kangaroo Valley, Kiama, Milton, Minnamurra, Nowra, Shellharbour, Shell Cove, Sussex Inlet, Ulladulla and Warilla.

[[Eriophorum]]

CATEGORIES: Poales

Eriophorum (also called cotton grass) is a genus of about 25 species of flowering plants. It is in the family Cyperaceae. They grow in temperate regions in the Northern Hemisphere. They are especially abundant in Arctic tundra regions.

[[Sevenoaks School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, 1432 establishments, Kent, 1430s establishments in Europe, 15th century establishments in England

Sevenoaks School is an English co-educational public school in Kent. It is a member of the G20 Schools Group. It is the second oldest non-denominational school in the United Kingdom, dating back to 1432, behind Oswestry (1407). Over 1,000 day pupils and boarders attend, ranging in age from 11 to 18 years. There are approximately equal numbers of boys and girls. 

It was the first school in England to switch to the International Baccalaureate instead of the usual A-Level exams.

[[Hotchkiss School]]

CATEGORIES: 1891 establishments in the United States, Schools in Connecticut, 19th-century establishments in Connecticut

Hotchkiss School is a prep boarding school in the state of Connecticut in the United States. It is a member of the G20 Schools Group and Round Square. For boarders it costs $49,940 including technology and health services fees. It started in 1891.

[[King Ecgbert School]]

CATEGORIES: Schools in England, Sheffield

King Ecgbert School is a secondary school in Sheffield, England. Ofsted rated it as 'good'.

[[Betty Shabazz]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 1997 deaths, Accidental deaths in the United States, African-American people, American civil rights activists, American manslaughter victims, American Muslims, People from Detroit, Michigan

Betty Shabazz was an American educator and civil rights activist. She was the widow of Malcolm X. 

She was born on May 28, in either 1934 or 1936. Her full name at birth was Betty Dean Sanders. She grew up in Detroit, Michigan. She and Malcolm X joined the Nation of Islam in 1956. They married in 1958. They had six children together. She raised them on her own after her husband was murdered in 1965.

Shabazz converted to Islam in 1965. Betty was pregnant with twin girls when she witnessed Malcolm X’s assassination. Betty never remarried after her husband’s death, and became a national figure. She also cared deeply about the struggle of people of African heritage in the U.S.

Shabazz's grandson Malcolm Shabazz (1984-2013) set fire to her apartment on June 1, 1997. She died of burns in hospital on June 23, 1997. He was convicted of arson and manslaughter and sentenced to 18 months juvenile detention.

[[Topographic map]]

CATEGORIES: Cartography

A topographic map is a kind of map which uses contour lines or other ways to show elevation and topography. Topo maps are usually very detailed, with a large scale, though some are not.  These maps are prepared based on detailed surveying of the areas concerned. 

Topographical maps may be used for many purposes.  They show relief features, rivers, land use, vegetation, settlements, roads, railway lines and administrative units and their boundaries. These maps are revised periodically to update them. Town guide maps are based on them.

[[Postage stamps and postal history of Macau]]

CATEGORIES: Postage stamps, Postal history, Macau

This is a survey of the postage stamps and postal history of Macau.

[[British Aircraft Corporation One-Eleven]]

CATEGORIES: Civil aircraft

The British Aircraft Corporation One-Eleven or sometime British Aircraft Corporation 111 or also BAC 111 was a British airliner. It was a twin-turbojet that could carry around one hundred passengers. Some were built under licence in Romania as RomBAC 111. This aircraft is similar to the French Sud Aviation Caravelle and to the US Douglas DC-9. The One-Eleven was retired from service in the 1990s because of noise restrictions. It was one of the more successful British designed airliners.

[[Softwood]]

CATEGORIES: Wood

Softwood is wood that comes from gymnosperm trees. These are conifers, a term which includes most evergreen trees. 

Softwood makes up about 80% of the world's production of lumber.  Traditional production areas include North America, Scandinavia, Baltic countries and China. The opposite of softwood is hardwood, which is wood that comes from angiosperm trees. Softwoods are not always softer than hardwoods. Both groups include a variety of wood types that vary in actual hardness. For example balsa is a hardwood but is softer than most softwoods. Douglas fir, a softwood, is much harder than many hardwoods. 

[[Detroit Lakes, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: County seats in Minnesota, Cities in Minnesota

Detroit Lakes it is a city and the county seat of Becker County, Minnesota, United States. The city's economy is based on tourism and agriculture. It attracts tourists in both summer and winter.

[[VFW-Fokker 614]]

CATEGORIES: Civil aircraft, German military aircraft

The VFW-Fokker 614 is a West German airliner. It is a twin-turbojets aircraft. Its uniqueness lies in the implementation of its two turbojets above the wing. VFW-Fokker 614 can carry between 40 and 44 passengers.

It was used by airlines in Denmark, France, and Germany until 2007. German Air Force, the Luftwaffe, also used this aircraft for speed liaisons and VIP transport.

Andreja Pejić (born 28 August 1991) is an Australian model and actress.

[[Vought F6U Pirate]]

CATEGORIES: United States Navy aircraft

The Vought F6U Pirate is a US navalized fighter aircraft that served in the U.S. Navy. It was one of the first military single-turbojet aircraft after World War II. Its first flight was in October 1946. Only 65 were ever built, and they were only used between 1947 and 1950.

[[Anna Grodzka]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1954 births, Bisexual people, LGBT politicians, Polish politicians, Transgender and transsexual people

Anna Grodzka (born 16 March 1954) is a Polish politician. In 2011, she was elected to the National Assembly as a member of the Palikot's Movement party. She became Poland's first transsexual Member of Parliament. She is the only openly transgender MP in the world. She went to the University of Warsaw. She is bisexual.

[[Mamphela Ramphele]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, South African politicians, South African writers, Activists, Living people

Mamphela Aletta Ramphele (born 28 December 1947) is a South African politician and writer. In February 2013, she started her own political party, Agang South Africa. Ramphele was previously an activist against Apartheid in South Africa.

[[Playaz Circle]]

CATEGORIES: Hip hop bands, 1997 establishments in the United States, Musical groups from Georgia (U.S. state), Musical groups established in 1997, 2013 disestablishments in the United States, 1990s establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Disestablishments in Georgia (U.S. state)

Playaz Circle were an American hip hop group from Georgia. The members were rappers 2 Chainz and Dolla Boy. The group was established in 1997 but did not began recording until 2007 with their best selling album. They were discovered by Ludacris and he signed them to his record label DTP. They are best known for their hit single "Duffle Bag Boy" that features Lil Wayne. In 2013 they broke up to work individually.

Fisher Ames (April 9, 1758 – July 4, 1808) was a United States Congress representative from the First Congressional District of Massachusetts.
