Tomáš Plekanec (born October 31, 1982) is a Czech professional ice hockey centre. He currently plays for the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League (NHL). He also played for HC Kladno of the Czech Extraliga and Toronto Maple Leafs (NHL).

Plekanec was born in Kladno, Czechoslovakia.

[[Ray Frederick]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2001 deaths, American Hockey League players, Brandon Wheat Kings players, Canadian ice hockey goaltenders, Chicago Blackhawks players, Ice hockey people from Ontario

Ray Frederick (July 31, 1929 - August 23, 2001) was a Canadian professional ice hockey goaltender. Frederick played a total of 5 games in the NHL with the Chicago Black Hawks during the 1954-55 NHL season.

[[North Indian Plain]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of India, Geography of Nepal, Geography of Bangladesh, Plains

The Gangetic Plains is the large space of level land that is made by the Ganges River in the northern parts of India and the border surrounding areas of the Himalayas. It is an important part of the countries of India, Nepal, and Bangladesh. Its space of about 700,000 is the home of about 1 billion persons (about one in every seven persons alive today).

Its western edge is the Thar Desert; its northern edge is the Himalaya Mountains, the highest mountains on Earth; its eastern edge is the Ganges Delta of Bangladesh, the largest River delta in the world; and its southern edge is made by the Vindhya Mountains and Satpura Range and Chota Nagpur Plateau of middle India.

[[Road safety]]

CATEGORIES: Road transport, Safety

                                                                                  Road safety is safety in using roads. Most years, traffic collisions kill about a million people worldwide. There are ways to make this less common, so roads will be safer for motor traffic, cyclists and pedestrians. It involves rules such as speed limits and those about drinking and driving, and control systems such as traffic lights and crossings. These are used to increase safety and reduce the chance of accidents.

[[Tata Steel]]

CATEGORIES: Companies of India

Tata Steel Limited (formerly Tata Iron and Steel Company Limited or TISCO) is an Indian multinational steel-making company. Their headquarters are in Mumbai. Tata is a subsidiary of the Tata Group. It was the 12th-largest steel-making company in the world in 2012. It can make about 23.8 million tonnes of crude steel each year. They are the largest private sector steel company in India measured by domestic production.

[[Prince du sang]]

CATEGORIES: Ranks in the old Kingdom of France

A prince du sang (prince of the blood) was a member of the extended French Royal Family. This meant that all people except females that were princes of the blood would be entitled to inherit the throne only if every male member of the immediate royal family had died. The main princes of the blood were known as the Prince of Conti and the Prince of Condé as well as the more significant Duke of Orléans. The prince of the blood was entitled to be styled Serene Highness (altesse sérénissime) but it was used in writing only. A majority of the princes of the blood had their own apartments at the Palace of Versailles as well as their own townhouses in Paris

[[Edward Williams Clay]]

CATEGORIES: 1799 births, 1857 deaths, American painters, American cartoonists, American printmakers, People from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, American lawyers

Edward Williams Clay (April 17, 1799 - December 31, 1857) was an American artist. He made a lot of different types of art. He made paintings and cartoons. He was also a printmaker.

[[Pennsylvania Bar Association]]

CATEGORIES: Pennsylvania, Law

The Pennsylvania Bar Association is an American voluntary association of lawyers and people going to school for law. It is located in the state of Pennsylvania and is for people who work in that state. In the year 2013, 28,000 people were a part of the association.

[[Billy Unger]]

[[Hattie Caraway]]

CATEGORIES: Cardiovascular disease deaths in Virginia, Deaths from stroke, United States senators from Arkansas, 1878 births, 1950 deaths

Hattie Ophelia Wyatt Caraway (February 1, 1878 — December 21, 1950) was the first woman elected to serve a full term in the United States Senate. She was the Senator from Arkansas for just over thirteen years (December 1931 to January 1945).

Caraway had a stroke in 1950. She died later that year in Falls Church, Virginia due to this stroke.

[[Division of Paterson]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1949 establishments in Australia, 1984 disestablishments in Australia, 1992 establishments in Australia

The Division of Paterson is an Australian electoral division in the state of New South Wales. It is just north of Newcastle, on the coast of the Tasman Sea. It includes the towns of Anna Bay, Bulahdelah. Clarence Town, Dungog, Forster, Hawks Nest, Lemon Tree Passage, Medowie, Morpeth, Nelson Bay, Paterson, Raymond Terrace, Stroud, Tuncurry and parts of Nabiac, Thornton and East Maitland. The division was first set up in 1949 and abolished in 1984. It was recreated after a redistribution in 1992.

The division is named after poet and author Banjo Paterson. It is possible that is was named after Colonel William Paterson who also gave his name to the Paterson River and the town of Paterson, both of which were in the electorate. It was first contested at the 1949 election.

In 1949 the division included Singleton, Maitland and Muswellbrook. Redistributions moved the electorate north until it included Gunnedah and Mudgee. The original electorate was abolished in 1984. In 1992 it was recreated covering a similar area to the original electorate. 

[[Elaine S. Edwards]]

CATEGORIES: US Democratic Party politicians, United States senators from Louisiana, Deaths from COPD, 1929 births, 2018 deaths

Elaine Schwartzenburg Edwards (March 8, 1929 – May 14, 2018) was a former United States Senator from Louisiana. She was a member of the Democratic Party. Edwards was the wife of Edwin Edwards, the former Governor of Louisiana. They were married from 1949 until they divorced in 1989. She was a Senator for three and a half months during 1972. Edwards was born in Marksville, Louisiana.

Edwards died on May 14, 2018 at her daughter's home in Denham Springs, Louisiana of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease at the age of 89.

[[Margaret Chase Smith]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from Maine, Deaths from stroke, 1897 births, 1995 deaths

Margaret Chase Smith (14 December 1897 — 29 May 1995) was an American politician. She was a member of the House of Representatives from 1940 to 1949, and a United States Senator from 1949 to 1973. She was from the Republican Party. She was the first female to be in both houses of the United States Congress.

Chase was born in Maine. She died after a stroke at age 97.

[[Eva Bowring]]

CATEGORIES: US Republican Party politicians, Politicians from Missouri, United States senators from Nebraska, 1892 births, 1985 deaths

Eva Kelly Bowring (January 9, 1892 — January 8, 1985) was a United States Senator from Nebraska. She was the first woman from Nebraska in the Senate. She was a Senator for seven months during 1954.

She was born in Missouri. She died the day before her 93rd birthday.

George Jerome Waldo Goodman (August 10, 1930 – January 3, 2014) was an American author and economics commentator. He was best known by his pen name Adam Smith. He also wrote fiction under his real name. 

Goodman died at the age of 83, at the University of Miami Hospital. He had suffered from the bone marrow disorder myelofibrosis.

[[Peter O'Sullevan]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2015 deaths, BBC people, Cancer deaths in London, Sportspeople from the Republic of Ireland

Sir Peter John O'Sullevan (3 March 1918 – 29 July 2015) was an Irish retired horse racing commentator. He worked for the BBC, the Press Association, Daily Express and Today. He was the BBC's leading horse-racing commentator from 1947 to 1997.

O'Sullevan was born in Kenmare, Ireland. He studied at Hawtreys, Charterhouse School, and later at Collège Alpin International Beau Soleil in Switzerland. O'Sullevan died of cancer in London, aged 97.

[[Rebecca Latimer Felton]]

Rebecca Ann Latimer Felton (10 June 1835 — 24 January 1930) was an American writer, lecturer and politician. She was in the United States Senate as a Democrat. She was from Georgia.

Latimer Felton was born in the Atlanta area. She died in the city of Atlanta, aged 94.

[[Oswald of Northumbria]]

CATEGORIES: Anglo-Saxons, 600s births, 640s deaths, Kings and queens

Oswald (605–642) was a King of Northumbria and the first Christian monarch of that kingdom. Oswald brought St. Aidan from Iona to start a monastery on the island of Lindisfarne. Oswald was also venerated as a saint.

[[Don't Turn Around]]

"Don't Turn Around" is a popular song. It was first sung by Tina Turner in 1986. It was not until 1988, though, when singers Bonnie Tyler and Luther Ingram made their own versions of the song, that it got really popular. The most famous version of the song was by Ace of Base in 1994.

[[All That She Wants]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 songs, Pop songs

"All That She Wants" is a hit single from Swedish pop group Ace of Base. It was released in 1992. The song hit #2 in the United States. It also topped the charts in Germany, Australia, United Kingdom and Denmark. The song was very popular in 1993.

The longest version was 7 minutes and 58 seconds long.

CATEGORIES: 1993 songs, Pop songs

Another version of this song lasts six minutes and 49 seconds.

[[The Woodlands (Philadelphia)]]

CATEGORIES: National Historic Landmarks of the United States, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Cemeteries in the United States, 1770 establishments, 1770s establishments in the Thirteen Colonies, 18th-century establishments in Pennsylvania

The Woodlands is a National Historic Landmark in the city of Philadelphia in the state of Pennsylvania in the United States. The Schuylkill River goes past The Woodlands. It has a mansion, a building to put a carriage inside (called a "carriage house"), and a garden that became a cemetery in the year 1840. Over 30,000 people are buried in the cemetery. 

[[Schuylkill River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Pennsylvania

The Schuylkill River is a river in the state of Pennsylvania in the United States. It is 135 long. It used to be called "Tool-pay Hanna" by the Lenape.

[[Pennsylvania Prison Society]]

CATEGORIES: Non-profit organizations of the United States, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Imprisonment and detention, 1787 establishments in the United States, Human rights organizations in the United States, 1780s establishments in Pennsylvania

The Pennsylvania Prison Society is a non-profit organization. It in the city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in the United States. It helps prisoners and their families. It also helps prisoners after they are out of prison. 

It was started in 1787. It used to be called the Philadelphia Society for Alleviating the Miseries of Public Prisons. It was founded by a group of men from Philadelphia. The group of men included Benjamin Franklin, Benjamin Rush, John Swanwick, Tench Coxe, Zachariah Poulson, and William White. William White was the president for a long time.

It now has many small organizations, called "chapters", around Pennsylvania. It has 43 chapters.

Irene Papas was born in Corinth in Greece. She stopped acting in 2003.

Some sources give 1929 as her real year of birth.

Warren Skorodenski (born March 22, 1960 in Winnipeg, Manitoba) is a Canadian retired professional ice hockey goaltender. Frederick played a total of 35 games in the National Hockey League (NHL) with the Chicago Black Hawks and Edmonton Oilers.

[[Mower Hospital]]

CATEGORIES: Hospitals in the United States, Buildings and structures in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, American Civil War, 1862 establishments in the United States, 1860s establishments in Pennsylvania

Mower Hospital was a military hospital in a neighborhood named Chestnut Hill, which is in the city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It was built in 1862 for soldiers who were in the American Civil War. It was run by the United States Army.

Architect John McArthur, Jr. designed the hospital. It was near the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad so hurt soldiers could be brought to the hospital fast. It was open from January 1863 until May 1865. 

It had room for 40,000 patients. It was shaped so that people would not get sicker or get an infection from other sick and injured people. It had many things for the people who worked there, and for the injured soldiers. People could go to a barber shop and go grocery shopping. It had lights powered with gas and fresh water. 

The hospital does not exist anymore.

[[Alicia Rhett]]

CATEGORIES: American movie actors, Actors from Georgia (U.S. state), Deaths from natural causes, 1915 births, 2014 deaths

Alicia Rhett (1 February 1915 — 3 January 2014) was an American painter and actress. She appeared in several movies, but was more known for painting portraits. She played India Wilkes in Gone with the Wind.

She was born in Savannah, Georgia. She died at age 98 in Charleston, South Carolina.

[[Merchants' Exchange Building (Philadelphia)]]

CATEGORIES: National Historic Landmarks of the United States, 1834 establishments in the United States, Buildings and structures in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 1830s establishments in Pennsylvania

The Merchants' Exchange Building is a building in the city of Philadelphia which is in the state of Pennsylvania in the United States. It is in a historical neighborhood called Old City. Architect William Strickland designed the building. It was built starting in the year 1832 and was done in 1834. The Merchants' Exchange Building was the first office building in the city. It used to be a brokerage house.  In 1875, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange moved into the building. 

In the year 2001 it became a National Historic Landmark.

[[Saul Zaentz]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Disease-related deaths in San Francisco, Movie producers from New Jersey, People from Passaic, New Jersey

Saul Zaentz (ˈ (February 28, 1921 – January 3, 2014) was an American movie producer. He also owned a record company. He won the Academy Award for Best Picture three times. In 1996, he was awarded the Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award.

Zaentz died in San Francisco, California. He was suffering from Alzheimer's disease. He was 92 years old.

[[Proxy war]]

CATEGORIES: Wars

A proxy war, or proxy warfare, is a war in which opposite sides use third parties as substitutes for fighting each other directly. States sometimes use less powerful states as proxies but more often use violent non-state actors, mercenaries, and other third parties, such as during in a civil war. They may give their proxies money, weapons, training, or other help. The hope is  to strike an opponent without a full-scale war, especially one that could involve the nuclear bomb.

The United States and the Soviet Union used many proxies to fight each other during the Cold War. Both sides tried to increase their influence and to decrease the other's influence.

[[Wim Kok]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Deputy Prime Ministers of the Netherlands, Dutch lobbyists, Dutch trade unionists, Former leaders of political parties in the Netherlands, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Government ministers of the Netherlands, Labour Party (Netherlands) politicians, Politicians from South Holland, Prime Ministers of the Netherlands

Willem "Wim" Kok (September 29, 1938 – October 20, 2018) was a politician and former trade unionist from the Netherlands. He represented the Labour Party (PvdA). He served as Prime Minister of the Netherlands from August 22, 1994 until July 22, 2002.

Kok was born in Bergambacht in South Holland.

Kok died on October 20, 2018 in Amsterdam from heart failure at the age of 80.

[[Josip Manolić]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, Living people, European military people, Majors, Military personnel of World War II, Prime Ministers of Croatia

Josip Manolić (born 22 March 1920) is a Croatian politician. He was the Prime Minister of Croatia from 24 August 1990 to 17 July 1991.

[[George H. W. Bush vomiting incident]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 in the United States, George H. W. Bush, 1990s in Japan, 1992 in Asia

The George H.W. Bush vomiting incident was an incident that occurred on January 8, 1992 at around 8:20 p.m. JST when U.S. President George H.W. Bush fainted after vomiting at a banquet hosted by the then Prime Minister of Japan, Kiichi Miyazawa. Bush vomited on Miyazawa's lap. Bush later made comments to the press that he had a 24 hour flu bug. The incident was widely reported, After the event, many comedians made fun of Bush because of the incident.

[[Harry Whittington]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, American lawyers, People from Austin, Texas

Harry M. Whittington (born March 3, 1927) is an American lawyer and real estate investor. He became famous in the media on February 11, 2006, when he was accidentally shot by Vice President Dick Cheney. Cheney was hunting quail with two women on a ranch in Kenedy County, Texas, near Corpus Christi.

[[Dick Cheney hunting incident]]

CATEGORIES: 2006 in the United States, 2000s in Texas

The Dick Cheney hunting incident happened on February 11, 2006, when then U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney shot Harry Whittington, a 78-year-old Texas attorney, while participating in a quail hunt on a ranch in Kenedy County, Texas. Both Cheney and Whittington called the incident an accident.

On February 14, 2006, Whittington suffered a non-fatal heart attack and atrial fibrillation due to at least one lead-shot pellet lodged in or near his heart. Cheney did not speak publicly about the incident until February 15 in an interview with Fox News. Early reports indicated that Cheney and Whittington were friends and that the injuries were minor.  Whittington has since told the Washington Post that he and Cheney were not close friends but acquaintances and has not said if Cheney apologized.

[[Kiichi Miyazawa]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2007 deaths, Prime Ministers of Japan, People from Hiroshima Prefecture, University of Tokyo alumni

Kiichi Miyazawa was a Japanese politician. Miyazawa was a member of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). He was the 78th Prime Minister, serving from 5 November 1991 to 9 August 1993.

Miyazawa died in Tokyo at the age of 87.

[[Mercedes Sosa]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2009 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Argentine singers, Latin Grammy Award winners

Haydée Mercedes Sosa (9 July 1935 – 4 October 2009) was an Argentine singer. She was popular throughout Latin America and many countries outside the continent. Sosa became one of the important examples of nueva canción. She gave voice to songs written by both Brazilians and Cubans. She was best known as the "voice of the voiceless ones".

Sosa suffered from breathing problems in later years. Sosa went into hospital in Buenos Aires on September 18, 2009. She died from multiple organ failure on October 4, 2009. She was aged 74.

Walk the Line is a American biographical drama movie based on the life of country singer Johnny Cash. It stars Joaquin Phoenix, Reese Witherspoon, Ginnifer Goodwin and Robert Patrick. It was released on November 18, 2005. It got positive reviews from critics.

Jennifer Michelle Goodwin (or Ginnifer Goodwin; born May 22, 1978) is an American actress. She played Margene Heffman in the television series Big Love. She also appeared on movies, including Mona Lisa Smile, Something Borrowed, Walk the Line, He's Just Not That Into You and Zootopia.

[[Robert Patrick]]

CATEGORIES: Saturn Award winners, 1958 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Georgia (U.S. state)

Robert Patrick (born Robert Patrick Hammond Jr.; November 5, 1958) is an American actor. He is known for his roles in Die Hard 2, Terminator 2: Judgment Day, Spy Kids, Walk the Line, Wayne's World, and in Identity Thief. He won a Saturn Award in 2000 for his role in The Sopranos.

[[John Fogerty]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, American rock guitarists, American songwriters, Writers from Berkeley, California, Singers from Berkeley, California

John Cameron Fogerty (born May 28, 1945) is an American musician, songwriter and guitarist. He is best known for his time with the roots rock band Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR), as well as his time as a solo musician.

Fogerty was born in Berkeley, California. The first band he was a part of was called The Golliwogs. He started this band with his brother Tom Fogerty, and Doug Clifford and Stu Cook.

In 1966, Fogerty served a United States Army Reserve unit at Fort Bragg, Fort Knox, and Fort Lee. In July 1967, he was discharged. At that time the band changed its name to Creedence Clearwater Revival. The band broke up in 1972. Since then, Fogerty has had a successful solo career.

He is currently married to Julie Kramer. They have one daughter from Kramer's previous marriage, two sons and a daughter.

[[Kola Superdeep Borehole]]

CATEGORIES: Earth sciences

The Kola Superdeep Borehole (Кольская сверхглубокая скважина, Kolskaya sverkhglubokaya skvazhina) was a very deep hole dug on the Kola Peninsula in Russia during 1970-1992 and closed by 2008. It was dug in order to learn more about the inside of the Earth. Digging started on May 24, 1970. The work continued until 1992, or 1994. The borehole was kept open until 2005. SG-3, the deepest part of the hole, reached 12,261 below the surface in 1989. That is the deepest hole ever made and is still the deepest man-made point on Earth.

For a long time, SG-3 was also the longest hole by distance from its opening. In 2008, the Al Shaheen BD-04A oil well in Qatar reached +27 farther and, in 2011, the Odoptu OP-11 oil well off Sakhalin got +83 farther.

[[Oliver Glasner]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, Austrian football managers, Austrian footballers

Oliver Glasner (born August 28th, 1974) is an Austrian retired football player. He is now assistant coach of FC Red Bull Salzburg.

[[On Denoting]]

CATEGORIES: Works of philosophy, Essays, 1905 works

"On Denoting" is an essay by Bertrand Russell from 1905. The essay was published in the philosophy journal Mind in 1905. It was reprinted, in both a special 2005 anniversary issue of the same journal and in Russell's Logic and Knowledge, 1956. The essay is one of the most significant and influential philosophical essays of the 20th century. In it, Russell introduces definite and indefinite descriptions, formulates descriptivism with regard to proper names, and characterises proper names as "disguised" or "abbreviated" definite descriptions.

In the 1920s, Frank P. Ramsey referred to the essay as "that paradigm of philosophy". In the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy entry Descriptions, Peter Ludlow singled the essay out as "the paradigm of philosophy", and called it a work of "tremendous insight"; provoking discussion and debate among philosophers of language and linguists for over a century.

[[The Chumscrubber]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 movies, American independent movies

The Chumscrubber is a 2005 movie. It got mostly bad reviews from movie critics. The main character, Dean Stiffle, was played by Jamie Bell. In the movie Dean's best friend Troy commits suicide.

[[Dr. Seuss' The Lorax]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 animated movies, American family movies, American animated movies, American criminal comedy movies, American adventure movies, English-language movies, Movies based on books by Dr. Seuss, Dystopian movies

Dr. Seuss' The Lorax is a 2012 American animated movie based on Dr. Seuss' book of the same name. It stars Danny DeVito, Ed Helms, Zac Efron, Taylor Swift, Betty White, Rob Riggle and Jenny Slate. It was released on March 2, 2012. The movie received positive reviews. It has songs like Let it Grow and How Bad Can I Be.

[[Geraldine James]]

CATEGORIES: English television actors, English movie actors, 1950 births, Living people

Geraldine James (born 6 July 1950) is an English actress. She has acted in television series, such as She's Been Away. She played Portia in a Broadway production of The Merchant of Venice in 1989. More recently, she acted in the movie Diana in 2013.

James was born in Berkshire, England.

[[Look Who's Talking Too]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 comedy-drama movies, 1990 romance movies, 1990s romantic comedy movies, 1990s romantic drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, American romantic comedy movies, American romantic drama movies

The movie Look Who's Talking Too is a comedy and drama movie. It was released December 14, 1990 in the United States. The movie is about childbirth and a couple wanting to be an average family. Kirstie Alley plays Mollie, Roseanne Barr voices Julie, John Travolta plays James and Bruce Willis voices Mikey. The movie received very negative reviews. Its overall box office, however, was moderately strong.

[[Division of Reid]]

CATEGORIES: Electoral divisions of Australia, New South Wales, 1922 establishments in Australia

The Division of Reid is an Australian electoral division in the state of New South Wales. It is named after the Right Honourable Sir George Reid, a former Premier of New South Wales and the fourth Prime Minister of Australia. Ot was set up in 1922.

The division is in the inner-western suburbs of Sydney. It includes Abbotsford, Breakfast Point, Cabarita, Canada Bay, Chiswick, Concord, Concord West, Drummoyne, Five Dock, Homebush, Homebush West, Liberty Grove, Lidcombe, Mortlake, Newington, North Strathfield, Rhodes, Rodd Point, Russell Lea, Silverwater, Sydney Olympic Park, Wareemba, and Wentworth Point; and includes parts of Auburn, Berala, Burwood, Croydon, and Strathfield.

[[Benton County, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: Indiana counties, 1840 establishments in the United States, 19th-century establishments in Indiana

Benton County is a county in Indiana. Its county seat is Fowler. About 93% of the land in the county is used for growing crops, mainly corn and soybeans.

[[Twink Caplan]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, American television actors, American movie actors, 1947 births, Living people

Twink Caplan (born 25 December 1947) is an American actress. She played Rona in the first two Look Who's Talking movies. She also played Miss Geist in the 1995 movie Clueless.

The actress was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

Fowler is a town in Benton County, Indiana, in the United States

Boone County is a county in Indiana. Its county seat is Lebanon.

[[Alex Cross]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 crime movies, 2012 thriller movies, 2010s crime thriller movies, 2010s mystery movies, American crime thriller movies, American mystery movies, American serial killer movies, English-language movies, Movies set in Detroit, Michigan, Lionsgate movies

Alex Cross is an American crime thriller movie. It was released in October 2012. It is about a police detective and psychologist who lives in Detroit with his family. He would like to leave Detroit for Washington, D.C.. But when his wife is killed, Alex goes looking for evidence against the killer.

Tyler Perry plays the title character. Cross was previously played by Morgan Freeman in Kiss the Girls and Along Came a Spider.

The movie critics did not give good reviews for Alex Cross. The movie did not do well at the box office.

[[Cicely Tyson]]

CATEGORIES: Drama Desk Award winners, Tony Award winning actors, Emmy Award winning actors, Models from New York City, American stage actors, American television actors, American movie actors, Actors from New York City, 1924 births, 2021 deaths

Cicely Tyson (December 19, 1924 – January 28, 2021) was an American actress. She played Sipsey in the comedic-drama movie Fried Green Tomatoes (1991), and played Mamma Kay in the movie The Haunting in Georgia (2013). She also played Carrie Grace Battle in the television series Sweet Justice.

Tyson was born in New York City. She died on January 28, 2021 in New York City at the age of 96.

[[Suchitra Sen]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2014 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in India, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Indian movie actors, People of British India

Suchitra Sen (6 April 1931 – 17 January 2014) was an Indian actress. She appeared in over 100 Bangladeshi movies. She was best known for her roles in Deep Jwele Jaai and Aandhi.

Sen was born near Pabna, Benagal. She was awarded the Padma Shri in 1972. Sen died on January 17, 2014 from a heart attack. She was aged 82. She had been admitted due to an infection.

[[Nicanor Parra]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2018 deaths, Chilean poets, Centenarians, Physicists, Mathematicians, Chilean scientists

Nicanor Parra Sandoval (5 September 1914 – 23 January 2018) was a Chilean poet, mathematicianSeptember 2017 and physicist. He was considered to be an influential poet in Latin America and one of the most important poets of Spanish literature. Parra had been nominated several times for a Nobel Prize in Literature.

Parra died on January 23, 2018, at 7:00 am, in La Reina, Chile, at the age of 103.

[[Fouad Ajami]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2014 deaths, American educators, American writers, Cancer deaths in the United States, Disease-related deaths in Maine, Deaths from prostate cancer

Fouad A. Ajami (فؤاد عجمي; September 18, 1945 – June 22, 2014) was an Lebanese-born American professor and writer. He was a senior fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution.

He was born in Arnoun, Lebanon. Ajami was an outspoken supporter of the Iraq War. He has also appeared on CNN multiple times.

Ajami died from prostate cancer in Maine, aged 68.

[[F. Murray Abraham]]

CATEGORIES: Academy Award winning actors, Golden Globe Award winning actors, 1939 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

F. Murray Abraham (born October 24, 1939) is an American actor. He won the Academy Award for Best Actor for his role as Antonio Salieri in Amadeus (1984). He is also known for his roles on The Name of the Rose (1986), Finding Forrester (2000), Inside Llewyn Davis (2013), All the President's Men (1976) and Scarface (1983). 

[[Carat (mass)]]

CATEGORIES: Units of mass

The carat is a unit of mass, which is used for gemstones and pearls. One Carat is equal to 0.2g. The current definition was adopted in 1907  at the Fourth General Conference on Weights and Measures. Officially, the carat can be divided into 100 pointsof 2 milligrams each.

[[Carat (purity)]]

CATEGORIES: Units of measurement

The carat is a unit of measurement for gold alloys. In that context, one carat gold means that the twenty-fourth part of an alloy is gold, the other parts are made of other metals, generally silver or copper. Pure gold would be soft,  which makes it unusable for many purposes. Alloyed gold is harder than pure gold and so more suitable for applications such as jewellery. An alloy that has 24 carat actually contains 99.9 percent gold, 18 carat gold contains 75 percent gold . Sometimes, a scale  up to 1000 is used; as an example, gold 585 mean there is 58.5 percent gold in the alloy. This means that "Gold 585" actually contains 14 carat.

[[Grudge Match]]

CATEGORIES: Sports comedy movies, 2013 movies

Grudge Match is a sports movie. It was released in December 2013. The movie is about major boxing fights. The fights happen after one of the participants is fired from the local shipyard. Robert De Niro plays Billy "The Kid" McDonnen, Sylvester Stallone plays Henry Sharp and Kim Basinger plays Sally.

The critics did not give good reviews for Grudge Match. Overall box office was not good.

[[The Hunger Games (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 science fiction movies, 2012 thriller movies, American science fiction movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books, Lionsgate movies, Post-apocalyptic movies, Dystopian movies

The Hunger Games is an adventure, drama, and science fiction movie. It is based on The Hunger Games, the first book in the Hunger Games trilogy by Suzanne Collins. The movie was directed by Gary Ross. It was released on March 12, 2012 in Los Angeles. In other places it was released on March 23, 2012.

The movie is set in the future in North America. It is about twenty-four teenagers fighting each other in the "Hunger Games". They fight until there is only one person left alive. It shows survival of the fittest in extreme conditions. The games are broadcast live on television in the whole country of Panem.

The movie is 142 minutes long. It is rated PG-13.

The reviews of the movie were mostly positive. Its box office performance was very good. 

The Hunger Games is a 2012 sci-fi adventure movie directed by Gary Ross made from Suzanne Collins’s book The Hunger Games. It is the first movie of many in the series. The story takes place in a distant future in the nation of Panem. Where a boy and girl is selected from each of the 12 districts to be in The Hunger Games. Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence) 2 volunteers to take her younger sister Primrose Everdeen. Katniss competes in The Hunger Games with another tribute from her district Peeta Mallark (Josh Hutcherson) 3.

Katniss and her family live in District 12, a coal-mining district and the poorest and the least amount of people among the districts. Katniss volunteers to take her sister’s place in The Hunger Games. Katniss competes in The Hunger Games with Peeta Mallark 3. Katniss uses her knowledge about hunting to win with her fellow tribute Peeta. This character from the Hunger Games is played by Jennifer Lawrence.

Peeta is a tribute from District 12 in the 74th hunger games. He fights in the Hunger Games with Katniss the female tribute. The two both win the Hunger Games by actively rebelling against the rules. Making a rebellion in Panem the nation they live in. This character from the Hunger Games is played by Josh Hutcherson.

Gale Hawthrone is a resident in District 12. He was close to Katniss due to their love of hunting. He has similar features to Katniss. He is a minor character in the first movie but has a bigger role later on. He loved Katniss in the first movie but had to hide his love as Peeta and Katniss had to play as "star-crossed lovers" deeply upsetting him.

[[Kaya Scodelario]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from London, English movie actors, English television actors, Models from London, 1992 births, Living people

Kaya Rose Scodelario (born Kaya Rose Humphrey; born 13 March 1992) is an English actress and former model. She plays Teresa in The Maze Runner in 2014. She also played Peshet in the 2010 movie Clash of the Titans.

Scodelario was born in London. She changed her surname to that of her Brazilian mother.

[[Laurel Hill Cemetery]]

CATEGORIES: Cemeteries in the United States, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, National Historic Landmarks of the United States, 1839 establishments in the United States, 1830s establishments in Pennsylvania

Laurel Hill Cemetery is a cemetery in the city of Philadelphia in Pennsylvania. It is a National Historic Landmark of the National Park Service. It is near the Schuylkill River. It is 3.5 miles north of Philadelphia.

A group of wealthy people from Philadelphia wanted a cemetery outside the city. They found a place for it in Laurel Hill. It used to be owned by a businessman named Joseph Sims. Building of the cemetery started in 1836. It was finished in 1839. The Scottish architect John Notman designed the cemetery. It was his first commission. There is a chapel. It is made in the Gothic architecture style.

Louis Antoine Godey, Sarah Josepha Hale, George G. Meade, John C. Pemberton, and many other famous people, are buried there.

[[Zoey Deutch]]

CATEGORIES: American television actors, American movie actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California, 1994 births, Living people

Zoey Francis Thompson Deutch (born November 10, 1994) is an American actress. She plays Rose Hathaway in the 2014 movie Vampire Academy: Blood Sisters. She also played Juliet Martin in the television show Ringer. She recently appeared as Stephanie Fleming in Why Him? (2016).

Deutch was born in Los Angeles, California. She is the daughter of Lea Thompson.

[[Great Central Fair]]

CATEGORIES: 1864 in the United States, American Civil War, Festivals in the United States, History of Philadelphia, 1860s in Pennsylvania, June events

The Great Central Fair was a fair that happened in June 1864. It took place in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It was held to raise funds for the United States Sanitary Commission. 

[[Dawson Creek]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in British Columbia

Dawson Creek is a city in the Canadian province of British Columbia. Dawson Creek is in the northeastern part of British Columbia. 

The population of Dawson Creek was 11,583 in 2011. The city is named after a creek that runs through. The creek itself is named after George Mercer Dawson by his land survey team when they passed through the area in August 1879.

[[Queen Charlotte, British Columbia]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in British Columbia

Queen Charlotte (or Queen Charlotte City) is a village in the Canadian province of British Columbia. It is located in the south end of Graham Island in the Haida Gwaii group of islands. It is on Skidegate Inlet.

The population of Queen Charlotte was 944 in 2011. The town was first established 1908 when the first sawmill in the islands began operating. The villagers worked to help supply Allied war planes with lumber during World War II. Within the year, three general stores, a drug and clothing store, two hotels, a pool hall, a boarding house, a barbershop and the local newspaper started operating in the village. The town gained a stable economy from the quick growth in the timber industry during the Great Depression.

[[Bob Vila]]

CATEGORIES: American television personalities, Writers from Florida, 1946 births, Living people

Robert Joseph Vila (also Bob Vila; born 20 June 1946) is an American home improvement television host. He hosted This Old House (1979-89), Bob Vila's Home Again (1990 to 2005) and Bob Vila (2005 to 2007). Vila has written ten books.

Vila was born in Miami, Florida.

[[Paz Vega]]

CATEGORIES: Spanish television actors, Spanish movie actors, 1976 births, Living people, People from Seville

Paz Vega (also Paz Campos Trigo; born January 2, 1976) is a Spanish actress. In the 2009 movie Triage, she played Elena. In the 2004 movie Spanglish she played Flor Moreno.

Paz Vega was born in Seville, Andalusia.

[[Janick Gers]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, English rock guitarists, Iron Maiden

Janick Robert Gers (born 27 January 1957 in Hartlepool, England) is an English guitarist. He currently plays for the heavy metal band Iron Maiden where he is one of three guitarist along with Dave Murray and Adrian Smith.

He uses the Fender Stratocaster and the Marshall JMP-1 preamp through a Marshall 9200 power amp.

[[Rachel Blanchard]]

Rachel Elise Blanchard (born March 19, 1976) is a Canadian actress. She played Hannah in the 2001 movie Sugar & Spice. She also played Maureen in the 2005 erotic movie Where the Truth Lies.

Blanchard was born in Toronto, Ontario.

[[Emmanuelle Vaugier]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian television actors, Canadian movie actors, 1976 births, Living people, People from Vancouver

Emmanuelle Vaugier (born 23 June 1976) is a Canadian actress, musician and fashion model. She played Detective Jessica Angell on CSI: NY. She also played Mia on Two and a Half Men. She has also been in some movies.

The actress was born in Vancouver, British Columbia.

[[Kate Mara]]

CATEGORIES: American television actors, American movie actors, American stage actors, 1983 births, Living people, Actors from New York

Kate Mara (born February 27, 1983) is an American actress. She played Alma Del Mar Jr. in the movie Brokeback Mountain. She also played Jessica Chandler for Random Hearts in 1999. She has also performed on stage. In 2017, she starred as Mary Jo Kopechne in Chappaquiddick. She played Zoe Barnes on House of Cards.

Mara was born in Bedford, New York.

[[Battle of Wilson's Creek]]

CATEGORIES: 1861 in the United States, American Civil War battles, 19th century in Missouri

The Battle of Wilson's Creek, also called the "Bull Run of the West", was a battle of the American Civil War. It was the first battle that took place west of the Mississippi River. Nathaniel Lyon, the Union general, was the first general killed in the Civil war.

[[Philadelphia Brigade]]

CATEGORIES: Union Army, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

The Philadelphia Brigade was a brigade in the Union Army during the American Civil War. It got its name because its soldiers came from the city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It was part of the Army of the Potomac.

[[Christina Grimmie]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, 2016 deaths, American pop singers, Murdered musicians, Murders by firearm in Florida, Singers from New Jersey

Christina Victoria Grimmie (March 12, 1994 - June 10, 2016) was an American pianist, musician and singer. She has performed cover versions of songs by Christina Aguilera, Selena Gomez and Demi Lovato. She released an extended play, Find Me, in June 2011. Her studio album With Love was released in 2013. A second EP, Side A, was released in 2016.

Grimmie was born and raised in New Jersey. She was shot dead in Orlando, Florida at age 22 at her concert.

[[Bianca Ryan]]

CATEGORIES: Musicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, American television personalities, 1994 births, Living people

Bianca Taylor Ryan (born September 1, 1994) is an American singer. She was the winner of NBC's America's Got Talent in its first season. Her first album, Bianca Ryan, was released in autumn 2006. In 2012, Ryan joined the cast of the independent movie We Be Kings. She played a teenaged musician who is guided by an angel to an ancient blues musician frozen in a blizzard.

Ryan was born and raised in Philadelphia.

[[Jodelle Ferland]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian television actors, Canadian movie actors, 1994 births, Living people, Actors from British Columbia

Jodelle Micah Ferland (born October 9, 1994) is a Canadian actress. She played Sharon and Alessa in the thriller movie Silent Hill (2006). She also played Mary Jensen in the miniseries Kingdom Hospital (2004) and Bree Tanner in the movie The Twilight Saga: Eclipse (2010). She began acting at age two.

Ferland was born in Nanaimo, British Columbia.

[[Dean Spielmann]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, Judges of the European Court of Human Rights, Lawyers, People from Luxembourg City

Dean Spielmann (born 26 October 1962) is a lawyer from Luxembourg. He is the President of the European Court of Human Rights. He has been a Judge of the European Court of Human Rights from Luxembourg since 2004. He was made President of the Fifth Section of the Court in 2011. He was made Vice-President and then later President in 2012.

[[Wamba]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Kenya, Towns in Africa

Wamba is a small town in Kenya. It is in the Samburu district. The Wamba administrative division is there. The town has a big Catholic hospital. The hospital is considered important to the Samburu district. The town plays a role in the tourism industry in Kenya. It has strong ties with Prince William of Britain due to his efforts to promote conservation and ties with Samburu communities.

[[Hockley County, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Texas counties

Hockley County is a county in the state of Texas in the United States. In 2010, 22,935 people lived there.  The county seat is Levelland.  The county was named for George Washington Hockley, who was Secretary of War for the Republic of Texas.

[[Weld County, Colorado]]

CATEGORIES: Colorado counties

Weld County is a county in the state of Colorado. The county seat is Greeley. As of the 2010 Census, 252,825 people lived there.

[[Gunnison County, Colorado]]

CATEGORIES: Colorado counties

Gunnison County is a county in the state of Colorado. The county seat is Gunnison. As of the 2010 Census, 15,324 people lived there.

[[Claiborne Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Louisiana parishes, 1828 establishments in the United States, 19th-century establishments in Louisiana

Claiborne Parish  is a parish of the state of Louisiana. The county seat is Homer. As of the 2010 Census, 17,195 people lived there.

[[Sergey Kozlov]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Russian footballers

Sergey Semenovich Kozlov (4 May 1960 – 4 January 2014) was a Russian football player and manager. Kozlov played as a midfielder and defender.

Kozlov died from problems after a heart attack on 4 January 2014. He was aged 53. He died in his hometown of Khabarovsk.

[[Bernard Glasser]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2014 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Movie producers from Chicago, Movie directors from Chicago

Bernard M. Glasser (June 3, 1924 – January 2, 2014) was an American movie producer and director. He was known for producing many science-fiction movies such as Space Master X-7, The Return of the Fly, Run Like a Thief and Triangle.

Glasser was born in Chicago, Illinois. He was married to Joan Glasser until his death. They had four children. Glasser died on January 2, 2014 from natural causes at his home in Los Angeles. He was aged 89.
